hebrew_text: אַרְבָּעָה רָאשֵׁי שָׁנִים הֵם, בְּאֶחָד בְּנִיסָן — רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה לַמְּלָכִים וְלָרְגָלִים.
human_translation: They are four New Year, On the first of Nisan is the New Year for kings; And for the Festivals,
llm_translation: Four heads of the year there are, on the first of Nisan — the head of the year for kings and for festivals.

hebrew_text: בְּאֶחָד בֶּאֱלוּל — רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה לְמַעְשַׂר בְּהֵמָה. רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמְרִים: בְּאֶחָד בְּתִשְׁרִי.
human_translation: On the first of Elul is the New Year for animal tithes; Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon say: on the first of Tishrei.
llm_translation: On the first of Elul — the New Year for tithing animals. Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon say: On the first of Tishrei.

hebrew_text: בְּאֶחָד בְּתִשְׁרִי — רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה לַשָּׁנִים וְלַשְּׁמִיטִּין וְלַיּוֹבְלוֹת, לִנְטִיעָה וְלִירָקוֹת.
human_translation: On the first of Tishrei is the New Year for years, for Sabbatical Years and Jubilee Years, for planting, and for vegetables,
llm_translation: On the first of Tishrei — Rosh Hashanah for years, for the release of debts, and for the Jubilee, for planting and for vegetables.

hebrew_text: בְּאֶחָד בִּשְׁבָט — רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה לָאִילָן כְּדִבְרֵי בֵּית שַׁמַּאי. בֵּית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: בַּחֲמִשָּׁה עָשָׂר בּוֹ.
human_translation: On the first of Shevat is the New Year for the tree; in accordance with the statement of Beit Shammai. Beit Hillel say: on the fifteenth of
llm_translation: On the first of Shevat — the New Year for trees according to the words of Beit Shammai. Beit Hillel says: On the fifteenth of it.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ לַמְּלָכִים, לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא? אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: לִשְׁטָרוֹת.
human_translation: for kings; with regard to what halakha Rav Ḥisda said: for documents.
llm_translation: Gemara: For kings, for what purpose? Rav Ḥisda said: For their decrees.

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן: שִׁטְרֵי חוֹב הַמּוּקְדָּמִין — פְּסוּלִין, וְהַמְאוּחָרִין — כְּשֵׁרִין.
human_translation: as we learned Antedated promissory notes, are invalid But postdated are valid,
llm_translation: We have learned in a Mishnah: promissory notes that are advanced are invalid, and those that are delayed are valid.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מֶלֶךְ שֶׁעָמַד בְּעֶשְׂרִים וְתִשְׁעָה בַּאֲדָר, כֵּיוָן שֶׁהִגִּיעַ אֶחָד בְּנִיסָן — עָלְתָה לוֹ שָׁנָה. וְאִם לֹא עָמַד אֶלָּא בְּאֶחָד בְּנִיסָן — אֵין מוֹנִין לוֹ שָׁנָה עַד שֶׁיַּגִּיעַ נִיסָן אַחֵר.
human_translation: The Sages taught a king ascended on the twenty-ninth of Adar, once the first of Nisan arrives, a year is counted toward his But if he ascended only on the first of Nisan, counts year toward his only the next Nisan arrives.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: A king who ascended the throne on the twenty-ninth of Adar, once the first of Nissan arrives - a year is counted for him. But if he ascended only on the first of Nissan - a year is not counted for him until another Nissan arrives.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: מֶלֶךְ שֶׁעָמַד בְּעֶשְׂרִים וְתִשְׁעָה בַּאֲדָר, כֵּיוָן שֶׁהִגִּיעַ אֶחָד בְּנִיסָן — עָלְתָה לוֹ שָׁנָה. הָא
human_translation: The Master said, a king ascended on the twenty-ninth of Adar, once the first of Nisan arrives a year is counted toward his This
llm_translation: Master said: A king who ascended on the twenty-ninth of Adar, once the first of Nissan arrives - a year is considered to him. Ha.

hebrew_text: קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּנִיסָן רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה לִמְלָכִים, וְיוֹם אֶחָד בַּשָּׁנָה חָשׁוּב שָׁנָה. וְאִם לֹא עָמַד אֶלָּא בְּאֶחָד בְּנִיסָן, אֵין מוֹנִין לוֹ שָׁנָה עַד שֶׁיַּגִּיעַ נִיסָן אַחֵר. פְּשִׁיטָא!
human_translation: teaches us that Nisan is the New Year for kings, and one day in a year is considered a year; But if he ascended only on the first of Nisan, a year is not counted toward his until the next Nisan arrives. obvious?
llm_translation: We hear that Nisan is the beginning of the year for kings, and one day in the year is considered a full year. And if he only ascended on the first of Nisan, they do not count a year for him until the next Nisan arrives. This is obvious!

hebrew_text: לָא צְרִיכָא, דְּאִימְּנוֹ עֲלֵיהּ מֵאֲדָר. מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא, נִימְנוֹ לֵיהּ תַּרְתֵּין שְׁנִין, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: No, necessary where appoint him in Adar. Lest you say should count the second year of his teaches us
llm_translation: Not necessary, for we have already established it from Adar. What might you say, that we have established it for him two years, this implies to us.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מֵת בַּאֲדָר וְעָמַד אַחֵר תַּחְתָּיו בַּאֲדָר — מוֹנִין שָׁנָה לְזֶה וְלָזֶה. מֵת בְּנִיסָן וְעָמַד אַחֵר תַּחְתָּיו בְּנִיסָן — מוֹנִין שָׁנָה לְזֶה וְלָזֶה. מֵת בַּאֲדָר וְעָמַד אַחֵר תַּחְתָּיו בְּנִיסָן — מוֹנִין רִאשׁוֹנָה לָרִאשׁוֹן, וּשְׁנִיָּה לַשֵּׁנִי.
human_translation: The Sages taught died in Adar and another succeeded him in Adar, one counts year to this one, and to that one, died in Nisan and another succeeded him in Nisan, one counts year to this one, and to that one, died in Adar and another succeeded him in Nisan, one counts the first year to the first and the second to the second
llm_translation: The sages taught: If one died in Adar and another arose in his place in Adar, we count a year for this one and for that one. If one died in Nissan and another arose in his place in Nissan, we count a year for this one and for that one. If one died in Adar and another arose in his place in Nissan, we count the first year for the first one, and the second year for the second one.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מַר: מֵת בַּאֲדָר וְעָמַד אַחֵר תַּחְתָּיו בַּאֲדָר — מוֹנִין שָׁנָה לְזֶה וְלָזֶה. פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: שַׁתָּא לְבֵי תְרֵי לָא מָנִינַן, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: The Master said: died in Adar and another succeeded him in Adar, one counts year to this one, and to that one, obvious? Lest you say one year cannot be counted toward two teaches us
llm_translation: Master said: "If one dies in Adar and another one stands in his place in Adar, we count a year for this one and for that one." It is obvious! What might you have thought? That we do not count a year for two in one house? It has been taught to us.

hebrew_text: מֵת בְּנִיסָן וְעָמַד אַחֵר תַּחְתָּיו בְּנִיסָן — מוֹנִין שָׁנָה לְזֶה וְלָזֶה. פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: כִּי אָמְרִינַן יוֹם אֶחָד בַּשָּׁנָה חָשׁוּב שָׁנָה — בְּסוֹף שָׁנָה. אֲבָל בִּתְחִלַּת שָׁנָה — לָא אָמְרִינַן, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: If died in Nisan and another succeeded him in Nisan, one counts year to this one, and to that one, obvious? Lest you say when we say one day in a year is considered year, at the end of the year, but at the beginning of the year we should not say it teaches us
llm_translation: Deceased in Nisan and another arose after him in Nisan - we count a year for this one and for that one. It is obvious! What might you have thought? When we say one day in the year is considered a year - at the end of the year. But at the beginning of the year - we do not say this, it is clear to us.

hebrew_text: מֵת בַּאֲדָר וְעָמַד אַחֵר תַּחְתָּיו בְּנִיסָן — מוֹנִין רִאשׁוֹנָה לָרִאשׁוֹן וּשְׁנִיָּה לַשֵּׁנִי. פְּשִׁיטָא! לָא צְרִיכָא, דְּאִימְּנוֹ עֲלֵיהּ מֵאֲדָר, וּמֶלֶךְ בֶּן מֶלֶךְ הוּא, מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: נִימְנוֹ לֵיהּ תַּרְתֵּין שְׁנִין, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: died in Adar and another succeeded him in Nisan, one counts the first to the first and the second to the second king obvious? No, necessary where appoint him in Adar, and he is a king, son of king, Lest you say two years should be counted toward his it teaches us
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "If one dies in Adar and another arises after him in Nisan — we count the first for the first and the second for the second." It is obvious! It is not necessary, for we establish him from Adar, and he is a king's son of a king. What might you say: let us establish for him two years, this is what he informs us.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מִנַּיִן לַמְּלָכִים שֶׁאֵין מוֹנִין לָהֶם אֶלָּא מִנִּיסָן — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיְהִי בִשְׁמוֹנִים שָׁנָה וְאַרְבַּע מֵאוֹת שָׁנָה לְצֵאת בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל מֵאֶרֶץ מִצְרַיִם בַּשָּׁנָה הָרְבִיעִית בְּחֹדֶשׁ זִיו הוּא הַחֹדֶשׁ הַשֵּׁנִי לִמְלֹךְ שְׁלֹמֹה עַל יִשְׂרָאֵל״. מַקִּישׁ מַלְכוּת שְׁלֹמֹה לִיצִיאַת מִצְרַיִם: מָה יְצִיאַת מִצְרַיִם מִנִּיסָן — אַף מַלְכוּת שְׁלֹמֹה מִנִּיסָן.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From where that one counts only from Nisan? As it is stated: “And it came to pass in the four hundred and eightieth year after the children of Israel were come out of the land of Egypt, in the fourth year of Solomon’s reign over Israel, in the month Ziv, which is the second month, juxtaposes the reign of Solomon to the exodus from Egypt: Just as the exodus from Egypt from Nisan, so too, Solomon’s reign from Nisan.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: From where do we derive that kings are only crowned based on the month of Nisan? As it is stated: "And it came to pass in the four hundred and eightieth year after the children of Israel were come out of the land of Egypt, in the fourth year of Solomon's reign over Israel" (1 Kings 6:1). He juxtaposes the reign of Solomon to the exodus from Egypt: Just as the exodus from Egypt occurred in Nisan, so too the reign of Solomon began in Nisan.

hebrew_text: וִיצִיאַת מִצְרַיִם גּוּפַהּ מְנָלַן דְּמִנִּיסָן מָנִינַן? דִּילְמָא מִתִּשְׁרִי מָנִינַן!
human_translation: And from where do we that we count the exodus from Egypt themselves from Nisan? Perhaps we count from Tishrei.
llm_translation: The departure from Egypt itself, from where do we count it? Perhaps we count it from the fifteenth of Nissan!

hebrew_text: לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיַּעַל אַהֲרֹן הַכֹּהֵן אֶל הֹר הָהָר עַל פִּי ה׳ וַיָּמׇת שָׁם בִּשְׁנַת הָאַרְבָּעִים לְצֵאת בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל מֵאֶרֶץ מִצְרַיִם בַּחֹדֶשׁ הַחֲמִישִׁי בְּאֶחָד לַחֹדֶשׁ״, וּכְתִיב: ״וַיְהִי בְּאַרְבָּעִים שָׁנָה בְּעַשְׁתֵּי עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ בְּאֶחָד לַחֹדֶשׁ דִּבֶּר מֹשֶׁה וְגוֹ׳״. מִדְּקָאֵי בְּאָב וְקָרֵי לַהּ ״שְׁנַת אַרְבָּעִים״, וְקָאֵי בִּשְׁבָט וְקָרֵי לַהּ ״שְׁנַת אַרְבָּעִים״ — מִכְּלָל דְּרֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה לָאו תִּשְׁרֵי הוּא.
human_translation: It should not enter your mind as it is written: “And Aaron the priest went up to Mount Hor at the commandment of the Lord, and died there, in the fortieth year after the children of Israel were come out of the land of Egypt, in the fifth month, on the first day of the month” and it is written: “And it came to pass in the fortieth year, in the eleventh month, on the first of the month, that Moses spoke From the fact that when speaks of Av, it calls “the fortieth year,” and when it speaks of Shevat, it calls “the fortieth year,” the implication is New Year not Tishrei.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "La sal'ka da'atach, dikhtiv: 'Vaya'al Aharon hakohen el hor hahar al pi Hashem vayamot sham bishnat ha'arba'im le'tzeit benei Yisrael me'eretz Mitzrayim bachodesh hachamishi be'echad lachodesh,' u'khtiv: 'Vayehi be'arba'im shanah be'ashtei asar chodesh be'echad lachodesh diber Moshe vego.' Mid'kaei be'av ve'karei lah 'shanat arba'im,' ve'kaei bishvat ve'karei lah 'shanat arba'im' — miklal d'rosh hashanah lav tishrei hu." English translation: "It did not enter your mind, as it is written: 'And Aaron the priest went up to Mount Hor at the command of the Lord and died there in the fortieth year after the Israelites had left the land of Egypt, in the fifth month on the first day of the month,' and it is also written: 'And it came to pass in the fortieth year, in the eleventh month, on the first day of the month, that Moses spoke, etc.' Since it is written in Av and it is called 'the fortieth year,' and it is written in Shevat and it is called 'the fortieth year' — this indicates that the head of the year is not in Tishrei."

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא הַיְאךְ — מְפָרֵשׁ דְּלִיצִיאַת מִצְרַיִם, אֶלָּא הַאי, מִמַּאי דְּלִיצִיאַת מִצְרַיִם, דִּילְמָא לַהֲקָמַת הַמִּשְׁכָּן?
human_translation: Granted, this explicitly stated that from the exodus from Egypt, But this from where that from the exodus from Egypt? Perhaps since the establishment of the Tabernacle
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Bishlama hayekh - m'farash d'litziat mitzrayim, ella hai, mimai d'litziat mitzrayim, dilmah lahaqamat hamishkan?" English translation: "In truth, how - he explains that it is not for the exodus from Egypt, but this, from what is the exodus from Egypt, perhaps for the establishment of the Tabernacle?"

hebrew_text: כִּדְאָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: ״שְׁנַת עֶשְׂרִים״ ״שְׁנַת עֶשְׂרִים״ — לִגְזֵרָה שָׁוָה, הָכָא נָמֵי: ״שְׁנַת אַרְבָּעִים״ ״שְׁנַת אַרְבָּעִים״ — לִגְזֵרָה שָׁוָה: מָה כָּאן לִיצִיאַת מִצְרַיִם — אַף כָּאן לִיצִיאַת מִצְרַיִם.
human_translation: In accordance with Rav Pappa said “the twentieth year” “the twentieth year” by way of a verbal analogy, here too, “the fortieth year” “the fortieth year” by way of a verbal analogy: Just as here, from the exodus from Egypt, so too, here, from the exodus from Egypt.
llm_translation: As Rav Papa said: "Twenty years," "Twenty years" - for an equal decree. Here too: "Forty years," "Forty years" - for an equal decree: Just as here regarding the Exodus from Egypt - so too here regarding the Exodus from Egypt.

hebrew_text: וּמִמַּאי דְּמַעֲשֶׂה דְּאָב קָדֵים, דִּילְמָא מַעֲשֶׂה דִּשְׁבָט קָדֵים!
human_translation: from where that the incident of Av first? Perhaps the incident of Shevat first,
llm_translation: And from where do we derive the deed of Av the Elder, perhaps it is the deed of the tribe of Kadim!

hebrew_text: לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דִּכְתִיב: ״אַחֲרֵי הַכֹּתוֹ אֶת סִיחוֹן״, וְכִי נָח נַפְשֵׁיהּ דְּאַהֲרֹן אַכַּתִּי הֲוָה סִיחוֹן קַיָּים, דִּכְתִיב:
human_translation: It should not enter your mind as it is written “after he had slain Sihon” and when Aaron died Sihon was still alive, as it is written:
llm_translation: Your request is to translate the following Talmudic text into English word-for-word, maintaining the original style and format of Talmudic discourse. Here is the translation: Talmudic text: "לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דִּכְתִיב: ״אַחֲרֵי הַכֹּתוֹ אֶת סִיחוֹן״, וְכִי נָח נַפְשֵׁיהּ דְּאַהֲרֹן אַכַּתִּי הֲוָה סִיחוֹן קַיָּים, דִּכְתִיב:" English translation: "It did not enter your mind, as it is written: 'After he had struck Sihon,' and if Aaron's soul had found rest, would Sihon have remained standing, as it is written:"

hebrew_text: ״וַיִּשְׁמַע הַכְּנַעֲנִי מֶלֶךְ עֲרָד״, מָה שְׁמוּעָה שָׁמַע? שָׁמַע שֶׁמֵּת אַהֲרֹן, וְנִסְתַּלְּקוּ עַנְנֵי כָּבוֹד, וּכְסָבוּר נִיתְּנָה רְשׁוּת לְהִלָּחֵם בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל. וְהַיְינוּ דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיִּרְאוּ כׇּל הָעֵדָה כִּי גָוַע אַהֲרֹן״,
human_translation: “And when the Canaanite, the king of Arad, heard What report did he hear? He heard that Aaron had died, and that the clouds of glory had withdrawn and he thought he had been granted permission to wage war against the Jewish people. And this is as it is written: “And all the congregation saw that [ ki ] Aaron was dead,
llm_translation: "And the Canaanite, the king of Arad, heard." What news did he hear? He heard that Aaron had died, and the clouds of glory departed, and he thought that permission had been granted to wage war against Israel. And this is what is written: "And all the congregation saw that Aaron had perished."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: אַל תִּקְרֵי ״וַיִּרְאוּ״, אֶלָּא ״וַיִּירָאוּ״, כִּדְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ. דְּאָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ, ״כִּי״ מְשַׁמֵּשׁ בְּאַרְבַּע לְשׁוֹנוֹת: אִי, דִּילְמָא, אֶלָּא, דְּהָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu said: Do not read “And they saw [ vayiru ]”; rather, “And they were seen [ vayeira’u ]” And in accordance with Reish Lakish, as Reish Lakish said: ki is used in four senses: If, perhaps, but, and because.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Avahu said: Do not read "וַיִּרְאוּ", rather "וַיִּירָאוּ", as Reish Lakish expounded. For Reish Lakish said, "כִּי" serves in four languages: perhaps, but, rather, this.

hebrew_text: מִי דָּמֵי? הָתָם כְּנַעַן, הָכָא סִיחוֹן! תָּנָא: הוּא סִיחוֹן, הוּא עֲרָד, הוּא כְּנַעַן. סִיחוֹן — שֶׁדּוֹמֶה לִסְיָיח בַּמִּדְבָּר, כְּנַעַן — עַל שֵׁם מַלְכוּתוֹ, וּמָה שְׁמוֹ — עֲרָד שְׁמוֹ. אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי: עֲרָד — שֶׁדּוֹמֶה לְעָרוֹד בַּמִּדְבָּר, כְּנַעַן — עַל שֵׁם מַלְכוּתוֹ, וּמָה שְׁמוֹ — סִיחוֹן שְׁמוֹ.
human_translation: Is it comparable? There, Canaan, here, Sihon. taught He is Sihon, he is Arad, he is Canaan. Sihon because he was similar to a foal [ seyyaḥ ] in the desert; Canaan after his kingdom, and what was his name? Arad was his name. Some say Arad because he was similar to a wild ass [ arod ] in the desert; Canaan after his kingdom; and what was his name? Sihon was his name.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Who is similar? There, it is Canaan, here it is Sihon! It was taught: He is Sihon, he is Arad, he is Canaan. Sihon - who is likened to a wandering in the desert, Canaan - named after his kingdom, and what is his name - Arad is his name. There are those who say: Arad - who is likened to a wild donkey in the desert, Canaan - named after his kingdom, and what is his name - Sihon is his name.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה אִיָּיר!
human_translation: Say New Year is Iyyar.
llm_translation: And why not Rosh Hashanah Iyyar!

hebrew_text: לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיְהִי בַּחֹדֶשׁ הָרִאשׁוֹן בַּשָּׁנָה הַשֵּׁנִית בְּאֶחָד לַחֹדֶשׁ הוּקַם הַמִּשְׁכָּן״, וּכְתִיב: ״וַיְהִי בַּשָּׁנָה הַשֵּׁנִית בַּחֹדֶשׁ הַשֵּׁנִי נַעֲלָה הֶעָנָן מֵעַל מִשְׁכַּן הָעֵדוּת״, מִדְּקָאֵי בְּנִיסָן וְקָרֵי לַהּ ״שָׁנָה שֵׁנִית״, וְקָאֵי בְּאִיָּיר וְקָרֵי לַהּ ״שָׁנָה שֵׁנִית״ — מִכְּלָל דְּרֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה לָאו אִיָּיר הוּא!
human_translation: It should not enter your mind as it is written: “And it came to pass in the first month in the second year, on the first day of the month, that the Tabernacle was established” and it is written: “And it came to pass in the second year, in the second month, that the cloud was taken up from over the Tabernacle of the testimony” From that when speaks of Nisan, it calls it “the second year,” and when it speaks of Iyyar, it calls it “the second year,” by inference, Rosh HaShana is not Iyyar.
llm_translation: Not gone up your mind, as it is written: "And it was in the first month, in the second year, on the first of the month, the Tabernacle was erected," and it is written: "And it was in the second year, in the second month, the cloud was lifted from over the Tabernacle of the Testimony," since it is established in Nisan and called it "the second year," and it is established in Iyyar and called it "the second year" — from the principle that the head of the year is not in Iyyar!

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה סִיוָן? לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דִּכְתִיב: ״בַּחֹדֶשׁ הַשְּׁלִישִׁי לְצֵאת בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל מֵאֶרֶץ מִצְרַיִם״, וְאִם אִיתָא — ״בַּחֹדֶשׁ הַשְּׁלִישִׁי בַּשָּׁנָה הַשֵּׁנִית לְצֵאת וְגוֹ׳״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
human_translation: And say New Year is Sivan. It should not enter your mind as it is written: “In the third month, after the children of Israel had gone out of the land of Egypt, And if it is so should have In the third month, in the second year after had gone out
llm_translation: And why not Rosh Hashanah in Sivan? It is not according to your opinion, as it is written: "In the third month after the children of Israel had gone forth out of the land of Egypt." And if you wish, it can be understood as: "In the third month in the second year after they had gone forth, etc." This is what is required!

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא תַּמּוּז! וְאֵימָא אָב! וְאֵימָא אֲדָר!
human_translation: But say Tammuz; or say Av; or say Adar.
llm_translation: And why not Tamuz! And why not Av! And why not Adar!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, מֵהָכָא: ״וַיָּחֶל לִבְנוֹת בַּחֹדֶשׁ הַשֵּׁנִי בַּשֵּׁנִי בִּשְׁנַת אַרְבַּע לְמַלְכוּתוֹ״. מַאי ״שֵׁנִי״? לָאו שֵׁנִי לְיֶרַח שֶׁמּוֹנִין בּוֹ לְמַלְכוּתוֹ?!
human_translation: Rather, Rabbi Elazar said: from here “And he began to build in the second month, in the second, in the fourth year of his reign” What is “the second”? Doesn’t it second to the month from which reign is counted?
llm_translation: Rather, Rabbi Elazar said from here: "And he began to build in the second month of the second year of his reign." What is "second"? Is it not the second month, which counts for his reign?!

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רָבִינָא: וְאֵימָא שֵׁנִי בַּחֹדֶשׁ! אִם כֵּן, ״שֵׁנִי בַּחֹדֶשׁ״ בְּהֶדְיָא הֲוָה כְּתִיב בֵּיהּ.
human_translation: Ravina strongly objects to this: say the second of the month? If so, it should have explicitly stated: “On the second of the month,”
llm_translation: Ravina objects to this: But say it was on the second of the month! If so, "on the second of the month" would have been explicitly written in it.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא בְּשֵׁנִי בַּשַּׁבָּת! חֲדָא, דְּלָא אַשְׁכְּחַן שֵׁנִי בַּשַּׁבָּת דִּכְתִיב. וְעוֹד: מַקִּישׁ שֵׁנִי בָּתְרָא לְשֵׁנִי קַמָּא: מָה שֵׁנִי קַמָּא — חֹדֶשׁ, אַף שֵׁנִי בָּתְרָא — חֹדֶשׁ.
human_translation: say of the week? First, we have not found the second of the week written; And further, juxtaposes the second “second” to the first “second”: Just as the first “second” a month, so too, the latter “second” a month.
llm_translation: And why not on the second day of Shabbat! One, for we do not find the second day of Shabbat mentioned in the verse. And furthermore, it compares the second to the first: just as the first is a month, so too the second is a month.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מִנַּיִין שֶׁאֵין מוֹנִין לָהֶם לַמְּלָכִים אֶלָּא מִנִּיסָן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיְהִי בִשְׁמוֹנִים שָׁנָה וְאַרְבַּע מֵאוֹת שָׁנָה לְצֵאת בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל מֵאֶרֶץ מִצְרַיִם וְגוֹ׳״, וּכְתִיב: ״וַיַּעַל אַהֲרֹן הַכֹּהֵן אֶל הֹר הָהָר עַל פִּי ה׳ וְגוֹ׳״, וּכְתִיב: ״וַיְהִי בְּאַרְבָּעִים שָׁנָה בְּעַשְׁתֵּי עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ״.
human_translation: is taught in accordance with of Rabbi Yoḥanan: From where that one counts kings’ only from Nisan? As it is stated: “And it came to pass in the four hundred and eightieth year after the children of Israel were come out of the land of Egypt, And it is written: “And Aaron the priest went up to Mount Hor at the commandment of the Lord, And it is written: “And it came to pass in the fortieth year, in the eleventh month,
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Rabbi Yochanan: From where do we derive that we do not count years for kings except from Nisan? As it is stated: "And it came to pass at the end of four hundred and thirty years, even the selfsame day it came to pass, that all the hosts of the Lord went out from the land of Egypt" (Exodus 12:41). And it is written: "And Aaron the priest went up into Mount Hor at the command of the Lord" (Numbers 33:38). And it is written: "And it came to pass in the fortieth year, in the eleventh month" (Deuteronomy 1:3).

hebrew_text: וּכְתִיב: ״אַחֲרֵי הַכּוֹתוֹ אֶת סִיחוֹן וְגוֹ׳״, וְאוֹמֵר: ״וַיִּשְׁמַע הַכְּנַעֲנִי וְגוֹ׳״, וְאוֹמֵר: ״וַיִּרְאוּ כׇּל הָעֵדָה כִּי גָוַע אַהֲרֹן וְגוֹ׳״, וְאוֹמֵר: ״וַיְהִי בַּחֹדֶשׁ הָרִאשׁוֹן בַּשָּׁנָה הַשֵּׁנִית וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: And it is written: “After he had slain Sihon, And it says: “And when the Canaanite, heard” And it says: “And all the congregation saw that Aaron was dead, And it says: “And it came to pass in the first month in the second year,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it is written: "After he had struck Sihon, etc.," and it says: "And the Canaanite heard, etc.," and it says: "And all the congregation saw that Aaron had perished, etc.," and it says: "And it came to pass in the first month of the second year, etc."

hebrew_text: וְאוֹמֵר: ״וַיְהִי בַּשָּׁנָה הַשֵּׁנִית בַּחֹדֶשׁ הַשֵּׁנִי וְגוֹ׳״, וְאוֹמֵר: ״בַּחֹדֶשׁ הַשְּׁלִישִׁי לְצֵאת בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְגוֹ׳״, וְאוֹמֵר: ״וַיָּחֶל לִבְנוֹת וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: And it says: “And it came to pass in the second year, in the second month, And it says: “In the third month, after the children of Israel had gone out And it says: “And he began to build
llm_translation: And he says: "And it was in the second year, in the second month, etc." And he says: "In the third month after the children of Israel had gone out, etc." And he says: "And he began to build, etc."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא לְמַלְכֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל, אֲבָל לְמַלְכֵי אוּמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם — מִתִּשְׁרִי מָנִינַן, ״שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״דִּבְרֵי נְחֶמְיָה בֶּן חֲכַלְיָה וַיְהִי בְחֹדֶשׁ כִּסְלֵיו שְׁנַת עֶשְׂרִים וְגוֹ׳״, וּכְתִיב: ״וַיְהִי בְּחֹדֶשׁ נִיסָן שְׁנַת עֶשְׂרִים לְאַרְתַּחְשַׁסְתְּא וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: They taught only with regard to the kings of Israel, but the kings of the nations of the world are counted from Tishrei, as it is stated: “The words of Nehemiah, son of Hachaliah. And it came to pass in the month Kislev, in the twentieth year, And it is written: “And it came to pass in the month Nisan, in the twentieth year of Artaxerxes
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisdah said: They only taught this regarding the kings of Israel, but regarding the kings of the nations of the world — from where do we derive it? As it is stated: "The words of Nehemiah son of Hacaliah. And it was in the month of Kislev, in the twentieth year, etc." And it is written: "And it was in the month of Nisan, in the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes, etc."

hebrew_text: מִדְּקָאֵי בְּכִסְלֵיו וְקָרֵי לֵיהּ ״שְׁנַת עֶשְׂרִים״, וְקָאֵי בְּנִיסָן וְקָרֵי לֵיהּ ״שְׁנַת עֶשְׂרִים״ — מִכְּלָל דְּרֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה לָאו נִיסָן הוּא.
human_translation: From that when speaks of Kislev it calls it the twentieth year, and when it speaks of Nisan it calls it the twentieth year, by inference, New Year does not Nisan.
llm_translation: From when it enters in Kislev and he calls it "the year twenty," and it enters in Nisan and he calls it "the year twenty" - from the inference that Rosh Hashanah is not in Nisan.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא הַיְאךְ — מְפָרֵשׁ דִּלְאַרְתַּחְשַׁסְתְּא, אֶלָּא הַאי — מִמַּאי דִּלְאַרְתַּחְשַׁסְתְּא? דִּילְמָא
human_translation: Granted, this it is explicitly stated of Artaxerxes. But that from where of Artaxerxes? Perhaps
llm_translation: In peace, how - explains that not of Artaxerxes, rather this - from what not of Artaxerxes? Perhaps

hebrew_text: לְמִנְיָנָא אַחֲרִינָא הוּא? אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: ״שְׁנַת עֶשְׂרִים״ ״שְׁנַת עֶשְׂרִים״ — לִגְזֵירָה שָׁוָה: מָה הָתָם לְאַרְתַּחְשַׁסְתְּא, אַף הָכָא לְאַרְתַּחְשַׁסְתְּא.
human_translation: it other count. Rav Pappa said: “the twentieth year” “the twentieth year” by way of a verbal analogy: Just as there of Artaxerxes, so too, here of Artaxerxes.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Regarding another count? Rav Papa said: 'Twenty years,' 'twenty years' - for an equal decree: just as there, for Artaxerxes, so too here, for Artaxerxes." English translation:

hebrew_text: וּמִמַּאי דְּמַעֲשֶׂה דְּכִסְלֵיו קָדֵים, דִּילְמָא מַעֲשֶׂה דְּנִיסָן קָדֵים?
human_translation: from where that the incident in Kislev took place first? Perhaps the incident in Nisan took place first,
llm_translation: And from what is it derived that the act of the Kislev month precedes, perhaps the act of Nissan precedes?

hebrew_text: לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דְּתַנְיָא: דְּבָרִים שֶׁאָמַר חֲנָנִי לִנְחֶמְיָה בְּכִסְלֵיו, אֲמָרָן נְחֶמְיָה לַמֶּלֶךְ בְּנִיסָן.
human_translation: It should not enter your mind as it is taught The words that Hanani told Nehemiah in Kislev, Nehemiah told the king in Nisan.
llm_translation: Not gone up your mind, as it was taught: The words that Hanani said to Nehemiah in Kislev, Nehemiah said to the king in Nisan.

hebrew_text: דְּבָרִים שֶׁאָמַר חֲנָנִי לִנְחֶמְיָה בְּכִסְלֵיו — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״דִּבְרֵי נְחֶמְיָה בֶּן חֲכַלְיָה וַיְהִי בְחֹדֶשׁ כִּסְלֵיו שְׁנַת עֶשְׂרִים וַאֲנִי הָיִיתִי בְּשׁוּשַׁן הַבִּירָה. וַיָּבֹא חֲנָנִי אֶחָד מֵאַחַי הוּא וַאֲנָשִׁים מִיהוּדָה וָאֶשְׁאָלֵם עַל הַיְּהוּדִים הַפְּלֵיטָה אֲשֶׁר נִשְׁאֲרוּ מִן הַשֶּׁבִי וְעַל יְרוּשָׁלִָם. וַיֹּאמְרוּ לִי הַנִּשְׁאָרִים אֲשֶׁר נִשְׁאֲרוּ מִן הַשְּׁבִי שָׁם בַּמְּדִינָה בְּרָעָה גְדוֹלָה וּבְחֶרְפָּה וְחוֹמַת יְרוּשָׁלִַם מְפוֹרָצֶת וּשְׁעָרֶיהָ נִצְּתוּ בָאֵשׁ״.
human_translation: The words that Hanani said to in Kislev as it is stated: “The words of Nehemiah, son of Hachaliah: And it came to pass in the month Kislev, in the twentieth year, as I was in Shushan the capital, that Hanani, one of my brothers, came out of Judah, he and certain men; and I asked them concerning the Jews who had escaped, who were left of the captivity, and concerning Jerusalem. And they said to me: The remnant who are left of the captivity there in the province suffer much hardship and insult; and the wall of Jerusalem is broken down, and its gates are burned with fire”
llm_translation: Words that Hanani said to Nehemiah in Kislev - as it is said: "The words of Nehemiah son of Hacaliah. Now it happened in the month of Kislev, in the twentieth year, while I was in Shushan the capital, that Hanani, one of my brothers, arrived with men from Judah. I asked them about the Jews who had escaped, those who had survived the exile, and about Jerusalem. They said to me, 'The remnant there in the province who survived the exile are in great trouble and disgrace. The wall of Jerusalem is broken down, and its gates have been destroyed by fire.'"

hebrew_text: אֲמָרָן נְחֶמְיָה לַמֶּלֶךְ בְּנִיסָן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיְהִי בְּחֹדֶשׁ נִיסָן שְׁנַת עֶשְׂרִים לְאַרְתַּחְשַׁסְתְּא הַמֶּלֶךְ יַיִן לְפָנָיו וָאֶשָּׂא אֶת הַיַּיִן וָאֶתְּנָה לַמֶּלֶךְ וְלֹא הָיִיתִי רַע לְפָנָיו. וַיֹּאמֶר לִי הַמֶּלֶךְ מַדּוּעַ פָּנֶיךָ רָעִים וְאַתָּה אֵינְךָ חוֹלֶה אֵין זֶה כִּי אִם רֹעַ לֵב וָאִירָא הַרְבֵּה מְאֹד. וָאוֹמַר לַמֶּלֶךְ הַמֶּלֶךְ לְעוֹלָם יִחְיֶה מַדּוּעַ לֹא יֵרְעוּ פָנַי אֲשֶׁר הָעִיר בֵּית קִבְרוֹת אֲבוֹתַי חֲרֵבָה וּשְׁעָרֶיהָ אוּכְּלוּ בָאֵשׁ״.
human_translation: Nehemiah told these to the king in Nisan, as it is stated: “And it came to pass in the month Nisan, in the twentieth year of Artaxerxes the king, that wine was before him, and I took up the wine and gave it to the king. Now I had not been sad before in his presence. And the king said to me: Why is your face sad, seeing that you are not sick? This is nothing else but sorrow of the heart. Then I was very much afraid, and I said to the king: Let the king live forever: Why should not my face be sad, when the city, the place of the tombs of my ancestors, lies waste, and its gates are consumed with fire?”
llm_translation: Nechemiah said to the king in Nisan, as it is stated: "Now it came to pass in the month of Nisan, in the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes, that wine was before him, and I took up the wine and gave it to the king. Now I had never been sad in his presence. So the king said to me, 'Why is your face sad, since you are not sick? This is nothing but sorrow of heart.' Then I became very much afraid. And I said to the king, 'Let the king live forever! Why should my face not be sad, when the city, the place of my fathers' tombs, lies waste, and its gates are consumed with fire?'"

hebrew_text: ״וַיֹּאמֶר לִי הַמֶּלֶךְ עַל מַה זֶּה אַתָּה מְבַקֵּשׁ וָאֶתְפַּלֵּל אֶל אֱלֹהֵי הַשָּׁמָיִם. וָאוֹמַר לַמֶּלֶךְ אִם עַל הַמֶּלֶךְ טוֹב וְאִם יִיטַב עַבְדְּךָ לְפָנֶיךָ אֲשֶׁר תִּשְׁלָחֵנִי אֶל יְהוּדָה אֶל עִיר קִבְרוֹת אֲבוֹתַי וְאֶבְנֶנָּה. וַיֹּאמֶר לִי הַמֶּלֶךְ וְהַשֵּׁגַל יוֹשֶׁבֶת אֶצְלוֹ עַד מָתַי יִהְיֶה מַהֲלָכְךָ וּמָתַי תָּשׁוּב וַיִּיטַב לִפְנֵי הַמֶּלֶךְ וַיִּשְׁלָחֵנִי וָאֶתְּנָה לוֹ זְמָן״.
human_translation: “Then the king said to me: For what do you ask? So I prayed to the God of heaven. And I said to the king: If it please the king, and if your servant has found favor in your sight, that you would send me to Judea, to the city of the graves of my ancestors, that I may rebuild it. And the king said to me, the consort also sitting by him: For how long shall your journey be? And when will you return? So it pleased the king to send me; and I set him a time”
llm_translation: "And the king said to me, 'Why is your face sad, since you are not sick? This is nothing but sadness of the heart.' Then I was very much afraid. I said to the king, 'Let the king live forever! Why should my face not be sad, when the city, the place of my ancestors' graves, lies waste, and its gates have been consumed by fire?' Then the king said to me, 'What do you request?' So I prayed to the God of heaven. And I said to the king, 'If it pleases the king, and if your servant has found favor in your sight, that you send me to Judah, to the city of my fathers' graves, that I may rebuild it.' Then the king said to me (the queen sitting beside him), 'How long will you be gone, and when will you return?' So it pleased the king to send me, and I set him a time."

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב יוֹסֵף: ״בְּיוֹם עֶשְׂרִים וְאַרְבָּעָה לַחֹדֶשׁ בַּשִּׁשִּׁי בִּשְׁנַת שְׁתַּיִם לְדָרְיָוֶשׁ״, וּכְתִיב: ״בַּשְּׁבִיעִי בִּשְׁנַת שְׁתַּיִם בְּעֶשְׂרִים וְאֶחָד לַחֹדֶשׁ״. וְאִם אִיתָא — ״בַּשְּׁבִיעִי בִּשְׁנַת שָׁלֹשׁ״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
human_translation: Rav Yosef raised an objection “On the twenty-fourth day of the sixth month, in the second year of Darius the king” and it is written “In the seventh month, in the second year, on the twenty-first day of the month, And if it were so what needed In the seventh month in the third year,
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: "On the twenty-fourth day of the month, in the sixth month, in the second year of Darius," and it is written: "On the twenty-first day of the month, in the seventh month, in the second year." And if you wish, you can say: "On the twenty-first day of the month, in the third year," it can enter!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: כּוֹרֶשׁ מֶלֶךְ כָּשֵׁר הָיָה, לְפִיכָךְ מָנוּ לוֹ כְּמַלְכֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל.
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu said Cyrus was a virtuous king, consequently counted of his like the kings of Israel,
llm_translation: Rabbi Avahu said: Cyrus the king was righteous, therefore they appointed him like the kings of Israel.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב יוֹסֵף: חֲדָא — דְּאִם כֵּן קָשׁוּ קְרָאֵי אַהֲדָדֵי, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְשֵׁיצִיא בַּיְתָא דְנָא עַד יוֹם תְּלָתָא לִירַח אֲדָר דִּי הִיא שְׁנַת שֵׁית לְמַלְכוּת דָּרְיָוֶשׁ מַלְכָּא״, וְתַנְיָא: בְּאוֹתוֹ זְמַן לַשָּׁנָה הַבָּאָה עָלָה עֶזְרָא מִבָּבֶל וְגָלוּתוֹ עִמּוֹ, וּכְתִיב: ״וַיָּבֹא יְרוּשָׁלִַם בַּחֹדֶשׁ הַחֲמִישִׁי הִיא שְׁנַת הַשְּׁבִיעִית לַמֶּלֶךְ״, וְאִם אִיתָא — ״שְׁנַת הַשְּׁמִינִית״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rav Yosef strongly objects to this One that if so, the verses contradict each other, as it is written: “And this house was finished on the third of the month Adar, which was in the sixth year of the reign of Darius the king” and it is taught At that same time in the following year Ezra went up from Babylonia together with his exiles. And it is written “And he came to Jerusalem in the fifth month, which was in the seventh year of the king” And if it were so what needed the eighth year
llm_translation: Rav Yosef objects to this: One - for if so, the verses of Ahadad were difficult, as it is written: "And the house of God in Jerusalem remained until the third day of the month of Adar, which was the sixth year of the reign of King Darius." And it was taught: At that time, in the following year, Ezra came up from Babylon, and his exile with him, and it is written: "And he came to Jerusalem in the fifth month, which was the seventh year of the king." And if it is so, it should have said "the eighth year."

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד: מִי דָּמֵי? הָתָם כּוֹרֶשׁ, הָכָא דָּרְיָוֶשׁ! תָּנָא: הוּא כּוֹרֶשׁ, הוּא דָּרְיָוֶשׁ, הוּא אַרְתַּחְשַׁסְתְּא. כּוֹרֶשׁ — שֶׁמֶּלֶךְ כָּשֵׁר הָיָה, אַרְתַּחְשַׁסְתְּא — עַל שֵׁם מַלְכוּתוֹ, וּמָה שְׁמוֹ — דָּרְיָוֶשׁ שְׁמוֹ.
human_translation: And further, Are comparable? There, Cyrus, here, Darius, taught He is Cyrus; he is Darius; he is Artaxerxes. Cyrus [ Koresh ] because he was a virtuous [ kasher ] king; Artaxerxes after his kingdom, and what was his name? Darius was his name.
llm_translation: And furthermore: Who is similar? There, it was Cyrus; here, it is Darius! It was taught: He is Cyrus, he is Darius, he is Artaxerxes. Cyrus - because he was a righteous king, Artaxerxes - named after his kingdom, and what is his name? Darius is his name.

hebrew_text: מִכׇּל מָקוֹם קַשְׁיָא! אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק, לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן קוֹדֶם שֶׁהֶחְמִיץ, כָּאן לְאַחַר שֶׁהֶחְמִיץ.
human_translation: In any case, it is difficult, Rabbi Yitzḥak said: This not difficult, Here, before he became corrupt, there, after he became corrupt.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "From all places difficult! Rabbi Yitzchak said, not difficult: here before it leavened, here after it leavened."

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב כָּהֲנָא: וּמִי הֶחְמִיץ? וְהָכְתִיב:
human_translation: Rav Kahana strongly objects to this Did he become corrupt But isn’t it written:
llm_translation: Rav Kahana objects to her: And who delayed? And it is written:

hebrew_text: ״וּמָה חַשְׁחָן וּבְנֵי תוֹרִין וְדִכְרִין וְאִמְּרִין לַעֲלָוָן לֶאֱלָהּ שְׁמַיָּא חִנְטִין מְלַח חֲמַר וּמְשַׁח כְּמֵאמַר כָּהֲנַיָּא דִי בִירוּשְׁלֶם לֶהֱוֵא מִתְיְהֵב לְהֹם יוֹם בְּיוֹם דִּי לָא שָׁלוּ״! אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי יִצְחָק: רַבִּי, מִטּוּנָךְ: ״דִּי לֶהֱוֹן מְהַקְרְבִין נִיחוֹחִין לֶאֱלָהּ שְׁמַיָּא וּמְצַלַּיִן לְחַיֵּי מַלְכָּא וּבְנוֹהִי״.
human_translation: “And that which they need, both young bullocks, and rams, and lambs, for the burnt-offerings of the God of heaven, wheat, salt, wine, and oil, according to the word of the priests who are at Jerusalem, let it be given them day by day without fail” Rabbi Yitzḥak said to My teacher, from your burden, “That they may sacrifice offerings of sweet savor to the God of heaven, and pray for the life of the king and of his sons”
llm_translation: "And what is Hashhan, and the sons of Torin, and Dikhrin, and they say to the upper world, 'To the God of heaven, we offer fine flour, salt, wine, and oil, as the priests in Jerusalem used to give them daily.' He said to him, Rabbi Yitzchak: 'Rabbi, from your storehouse: 'For they offer pleasing sacrifices to the God of heaven and pray for the life of the king and his sons.'"

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּעָבֵד הָכִי לָאו מְעַלְּיוּתָא הִיא? וְהָתַנְיָא, הָאוֹמֵר: ״סֶלַע זוֹ לִצְדָקָה בִּשְׁבִיל שֶׁיִּחְיוּ בָּנַי״, וּ״בִשְׁבִיל שֶׁאֶזְכֶּה בָּהּ לְחַיֵּי הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא״ — הֲרֵי זֶה צַדִּיק גָּמוּר.
human_translation: And one who acts in this manner, is not exemplary Isn’t it taught this sela for charity in order that my children may live, or: in order that through it I may merit life in the World-to-Come, he is a full-fledged righteous person?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And one who does so, is it not an act of merit? And it was taught: One who says, "This rock is for charity so that my sons may live," and "so that I may merit the life of the World to Come" — this one is a completely righteous person.

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל, כָּאן בְּגוֹיִם.
human_translation: This not difficult. Here, to a Jew. there, to gentiles.
llm_translation: Not difficult: here in Israel, here among the nations.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: מְנָלַן דְּאַחְמִיץ — דִּכְתִיב: ״נִדְבָּכִין דִּי אֶבֶן גְּלָל תְּלָתָא וְנִדְבָּךְ דִּי אָע חֲדַת וְנִפְקְתָא מִן בֵּית מַלְכָּא תִּתְיְהִב״, לְמָה לֵיהּ דַּעֲבַד הָכִי? סָבַר: אִי מָרְדוּ בִּי יְהוּדָאֵי — אִיקְלְיֵיהּ בְּנוּרָא.
human_translation: And if you wish, say: From where do we that became corrupt? As it is written with three rows of great stones, and a row of new timber, and let the expense be paid out of the king’s house” Why did he do it this He thought: If the Jews rebel against me, I will burn with fire,
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: From where do we derive that one may delay the bringing of sacrifices? For it is written: "If you offer a burnt offering of cattle, offer a male without blemish; you shall offer it at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, that it may be acceptable for you" (Leviticus 1:3). Why does it say to him to do so? He thought: If the Jews rebel against me, I will burn it with fire.

hebrew_text: אַטּוּ שְׁלֹמֹה לָא עֲבַד הָכִי? וְהָכְתִיב: ״שְׁלֹשָׁה טוּרֵי גָזִית וְטוּר כְּרֻתוֹת אֲרָזִים״! שְׁלֹמֹה עֲבַד מִלְּמַעְלָה, וְאִיהוּ עֲבַד מִלְּמַטָּה. שְׁלֹמֹה שַׁקְּעֵיהּ בְּבִנְיָנָא, אִיהוּ לָא שַׁקְּעֵיהּ בְּבִנְיָנָא. שְׁלֹמֹה סַדְיֵיהּ בְּסִידָא, אִיהוּ לָא סַדְיֵיהּ בְּסִידָא.
human_translation: Is that to say Solomon did not do this Isn’t it written: three rows of hewn stone and a row of cedar beams” Solomon placed above whereas placed below, Solomon sunk into the building did not sink it into the building. Solomon plastered with plaster whereas did not plaster with plaster.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Did Solomon not do so? But it is written: "Three rows of hewn stones and a row of cedar beams"! Solomon did from above, and he did from below. Solomon embedded it in the building, he did not embed it in the building. Solomon supported it with lime, he did not support it with lime.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף, וְאִיתֵּימָא רַבִּי יִצְחָק: מְנָלַן דְּאַחְמִיץ — מֵהָכָא: ״וַיֹּאמֶר לִי הַמֶּלֶךְ וְהַשֵּׁגַל יוֹשֶׁבֶת אֶצְלוֹ״. מַאי ״שֵׁגַל״? אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר לִימָא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב: כַּלְבְּתָא.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said, and some say Rabbi Yitzḥak From where do we that became corrupt? From here, “And the king said to me, the consort [ shegal ] also sitting by him: What is shegal Rabba bar Lima said in the name of Rav: a she-dog
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said, and some say Rabbi Yitzchak said: From where do we derive that one should delay the morning prayer? From here: "And the king said to me, with the queen sitting beside him." What is "queen"? Rabbah bar Lema said in the name of Rav: A dog.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה, הָא דִּכְתִיב: ״וְעַל מָרֵא שְׁמַיָּא הִתְרוֹמַמְתָּ וּלְמָאנַיָּיא דִי בַיְתֵיהּ הַיְתִיו קׇדָמָךְ וְאַנְתְּ וְרַבְרְבָנָךְ שֵׁגְלָתָךְ וּלְחֵנָתָךְ חַמְרָא שָׁתַיִן בְּהוֹן״, וְאִי ״שֵׁגַל״ כַּלְבְּתָא הִיא, כַּלְבְּתָא בַּת מִשְׁתְּיָא חַמְרָא הִיא? הָא לָא קַשְׁיָא, דְּמַלְּפָא לָה וְשָׁתְיָיא.
human_translation: However, if so, that which is written “But you have lifted up yourself against the Lord of heaven; and they have brought the vessels of His house before you, and you, and your lords, your consorts [ shegal ] and your concubines, have drunk wine in them” If shegal a she-dog, does a she-dog drink wine? This not difficult, as they trained it to drink
llm_translation: Rather from now on, this that is written: "And upon the master of the heavens you have exalted yourself, and they brought before you the vessels of his house, and you and your nobles, your wives, and your concubines have drunk wine from them." And if "concubine" is like a dog, is a dog the daughter of a female donkey? This is not difficult, for it is disgraceful to her and she drinks.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה דִּכְתִיב: ״בְּנוֹת מְלָכִים בְּיִקְּרוֹתֶיךָ נִצְּבָה שֵׁגַל לִימִינְךָ בְּכֶתֶם אוֹפִיר״, וְאִי שֵׁגַל כַּלְבְּתָא הִיא, מַאי קָא מְבַשַּׂר לְהוּ נָבִיא לְיִשְׂרָאֵל?! הָכִי קָאָמַר: בִּשְׂכַר שֶׁחֲבִיבָה תּוֹרָה לְיִשְׂרָאֵל כְּשֵׁגַל לַגּוֹיִם — זְכִיתֶם לְכֶתֶם אוֹפִיר.
human_translation: However, if so, which is written: “Kings’ daughters are among your favorites; upon your right hand stands a consort [ shegal ] in gold of Ophir” Now, if shegal is a she-dog, what is the prophet heralding for the Jewish people? This is what is saying: In reward for the Torah being as precious to the Jews as a she-dog is to gentiles, you merited the gold of Ophir.
llm_translation: Rather, from now on, as it is written: "The daughters of kings are among your precious ones; at your right hand stands the queen in gold of Ophir." And if "queen" is like a dog, how does the prophet bring good news to Israel?! This is what he is saying: In reward for the Torah that Israel cherishes, like a queen to the nations - they merit the gold of Ophir.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: לְעוֹלָם ״שֵׁגַל״ — מַלְכְּתָא הִיא, וְרַבָּה בַּר לִימָא גְּמָרָא, גְּמִיר לַהּ. וְאַמַּאי קָרֵי לַהּ ״שֵׁגַל״? שֶׁהָיְתָה חֲבִיבָה עָלָיו כְּשֵׁגַל. אִי נָמֵי: שֶׁהוֹשִׁיבָהּ בִּמְקוֹם שֵׁגַל.
human_translation: And if you wish, say: Actually, shegal consort, but Rabba bar Lima had a tradition And why was it called a consort [ shegal ]? because was as precious to him as a consort; or else, because he set in place of a consort.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: "Indeed 'Shegal' - she is a queen, and Rabbah bar Lema concluded the Gemara, he concluded it. And why is she called 'Shegal'? Because she was as beloved to him as a shegal. Alternatively: Because he seated her in the place of a shegal.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: מְנָלַן דְּאַחְמִיץ — מֵהָכָא: ״עַד כְּסַף כַּכְּרִין מְאָה וְעַד חִנְטִין כּוֹרִין מְאָה וְעַד חֲמַר בַּתִּין מְאָה וְעַד בַּתִּין מְשַׁח מְאָה וּמְלַח דִּי לָא כְתָב וְגוֹ׳״. מֵעִיקָּרָא — בְּלָא קִיצּוּתָא, וְהַשְׁתָּא — בְּקִיצּוּתָא.
human_translation: And if you wish, say: From where do we that became corrupt? from here, “Up to a hundred talents of silver, and up to a hundred measures of wheat, and up to a hundred bat of wine, and up to a hundred bat of oil, and salt without prescribed limit” Initially without a limit, but now a limit.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: From where do we derive that one may mix ingredients for the Passover offering? From here: "From a silver shekel to a silver kikar, the weight of a hundred shekels, from a silver kikar to a silver hin, the weight of a hundred shekels, from a silver hin to a silver bat, the weight of a hundred shekels, and from a silver bat to a silver log that is not written." Originally - without limitation, and now - with limitation.

hebrew_text: וְדִילְמָא מֵעִיקָּרָא לָא הֲוָה קִים לֵיהּ בְּקִיצּוּתָא? אֶלָּא, מְחַוַּורְתָּא כִּדְשַׁנִּיין מֵעִיקָּרָא.
human_translation: But perhaps initially he did not know what limit Rather, it is clear as we initially answered
llm_translation: Perhaps initially was not established for him in the beginning? Rather, a hole like a tooth from the beginning.

hebrew_text: וְלָרְגָלִים. רְגָלִים בְּאֶחָד בְּנִיסָן הוּא? בַּחֲמִשָּׁה עָשָׂר בְּנִיסָן הוּא! אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: רֶגֶל שֶׁבּוֹ, רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה לָרְגָלִים.
human_translation: And for the Festivals. Is Festivals on the first of Nisan? it on the fifteenth of Nisan, Rav Ḥisda said: the Festival that in is the New Year for Festivals.
llm_translation: And for the pilgrimage festivals. "Pilgrimage festivals on the first of Nisan?" It is on the fifteenth of Nisan! Rav Ḥisdah said: The festival that is his, Rosh Hashanah for the pilgrimage festivals.

hebrew_text: נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ לְנוֹדֵר, לְמֵיקַם עֲלֵיהּ בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״, וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא: אֶחָד הַנּוֹדֵר, וְאֶחָד הַמַּקְדִּישׁ, וְאֶחָד הַמַּעֲרִיךְ, כֵּיוָן שֶׁעָבְרוּ עָלָיו שְׁלֹשָׁה רְגָלִים — עוֹבֵר בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״.
human_translation: a practical difference to one who makes a vow, to determine when he is liable for You shall not delay. And Rabbi Shimon, as it is taught Whether one makes a vow or consecrates or makes a valuation, once three Festivals have passed he transgresses You shall not delay,
llm_translation: He went out from her to vow, to establish upon it with "do not delay," and Rabbi Shimon is it. As it was taught: One who vows, and one who sanctifies, and one who appraises, once three festivals have passed over him - he transgresses "do not delay."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: שְׁלֹשָׁה רְגָלִים כְּסִדְרָן, וְחַג הַמַּצּוֹת תְּחִילָּה. וְכֵן הָיָה רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַי אוֹמֵר: רְגָלִים, פְּעָמִים שְׁלֹשָׁה, פְּעָמִים אַרְבָּעָה, פְּעָמִים חֲמִשָּׁה. כֵּיצַד? נָדַר לִפְנֵי הַפֶּסַח — שְׁלֹשָׁה. לִפְנֵי עֲצֶרֶת — חֲמִשָּׁה. לִפְנֵי הֶחָג — אַרְבָּעָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: three Festivals in their order, with Passover first. And, so too, Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai would say: The Festivals are sometimes three, sometimes four, sometimes five. How so? If one made his vow before Passover three, before Shavuot five, before the festival four.
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: Three pilgrimage festivals in their order, and the Festival of Matzot first. And so Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai used to say: Festivals, three times three, four times four, five times five. How so? If one vows before Passover - three. Before Shavuot - five. Before Sukkot - four.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: חַיָּיבֵי הַדָּמִין וְהָעֲרָכִין, הַחֲרָמִין וְהַהֶקְדֵּשׁוֹת, חַטָּאוֹת וַאֲשָׁמוֹת, עוֹלוֹת וּשְׁלָמִים, צְדָקוֹת וּמַעַשְׂרוֹת, בְּכוֹר וּמַעֲשֵׂר וּפֶסַח,
human_translation: The Sages taught those who are liable for monetary or for valuations, for dedications, or for consecrations, sin-offerings, guilt-offerings, burnt-offerings, peace-offerings, charity, tithes, firstborn tithes, or the Paschal offering,
llm_translation: The sages taught: Those liable for bloodshed, valuations, things devoted, and consecrated items, sin offerings and guilt offerings, burnt offerings and peace offerings, tithes and first tithes, and Passover.

hebrew_text: לֶקֶט שִׁכְחָה וּפֵאָה, כֵּיוָן שֶׁעָבְרוּ עֲלֵיהֶן שְׁלֹשָׁה רְגָלִים — עוֹבֵר בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: שְׁלֹשָׁה רְגָלִים כְּסִדְרָן, וְחַג הַמַּצּוֹת תְּחִלָּה.
human_translation: gleanings, forgotten sheaves, or corner once three Festivals have passed they transgress You shall not delay. Rabbi Shimon says: three Festivals must be in their order, with the festival of Passover first.
llm_translation: Gleanings, forgotten sheaves, and the corner of the field, once three festivals have passed over them - one transgresses "Do not delay." Rabbi Shimon says: Three festivals in their order, and the Festival of Matzot first.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: כֵּיוָן שֶׁעָבַר עֲלֵיהֶן רֶגֶל אֶחָד — עוֹבֵר בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: כֵּיוָן שֶׁעָבְרוּ עֲלֵיהֶן שְׁנֵי רְגָלִים — עוֹבֵר בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״. רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: כֵּיוָן שֶׁעָבַר עֲלֵיהֶן חַג הַסּוּכּוֹת — עוֹבֵר עֲלֵיהֶן בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״.
human_translation: Rabbi Meir says: Once one Festival has passed, one transgresses You shall not delay. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: Once two Festivals have passed, one transgresses You shall not delay. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: Once the festival of Sukkot has passed, one transgresses You shall not delay.
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir says: Once one has passed over them with one foot - he may pass over with "Baal Te'acher." Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: Once two feet have passed over them - he may pass over with "Baal Te'acher." Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon says: Once the Festival of Sukkot has passed over them - he may pass over with "Baal Te'acher."

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּתַנָּא קַמָּא — מִכְּדֵי מִינַּיְיהוּ סָלֵיק, לְמָה לִי לְמֶהְדַּר וּמִיכְתַּב: ״בְּחַג הַמַּצּוֹת וּבְחַג הַשָּׁבוּעוֹת וּבְחַג הַסּוּכּוֹת״? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ לְ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״.
human_translation: What is the rationale of the first tanna ? Since has just concluded why, do I write again: “On the festival of Passover, and on the festival of Shavuot , and on the festival of Sukkot ; learn from here You shall not delay,
llm_translation: What is the reason that the first Tanna taught — because from their types it emerges, why do I need to beautify and write: "On the Feast of Unleavened Bread, and on the Feast of Weeks, and on the Feast of Booths"? Learn from it "do not delay."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר ״בְּחַג הַסּוּכּוֹת״, שֶׁבּוֹ דִּיבֵּר הַכָּתוּב, לָמָּה נֶאֱמַר — לוֹמַר שֶׁזֶּה אַחֲרוֹן.
human_translation: And Rabbi Shimon, says It was not necessary to say “on the festival of Sukkot ,” of which the text was speaking. Why, is it stated? to teach that this must be the last one,
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: It is not necessary to say "on the Feast of Tabernacles," for it is on this occasion that the Scripture spoke, why is it stated? To say that this is the last.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר — מַאי טַעְמָא? דִּכְתִיב: ״וּבָאתָ שָּׁמָּה ... וַהֲבֵאתֶם שָׁמָּה״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Meir, what is the rationale as it is written: and there shall you come: And there you shall bring
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir - what is the reason? As it is written: "And you shall come there... and you shall bring there."

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן — הַהוּא לַעֲשֵׂה.
human_translation: And the Rabbis, this a positive mitzva
llm_translation: The sages - that one to do.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר, כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר לֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא אַיְיתִי וְלָא אַיְיתִי — מִמֵּילָא קָם לֵיהּ בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Meir since the Merciful One tells one to bring and he did not bring automatically he is liable for You shall not delay,
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir, since he said to him: "The Merciful One brought it and did not bring it," immediately he arose with "Do not delay."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב, מַאי טַעְמָא? דִּכְתִיב: ״אֵלֶּה תַּעֲשׂוּ לַה׳ בְּמוֹעֲדֵיכֶם״ — מִיעוּט מוֹעֲדִים שְׁנַיִם.
human_translation: And Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, what is the rationale as it is written: “These things you shall do to the Lord in your appointed times, the minimum of appointed times is two.
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov, what is the reason? As it is written: "These you shall offer to the Lord at your appointed feasts" - a limitation of two appointed times.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן — הַהוּא לְכִדְרַבִּי יוֹנָה. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָה: הוּקְשׁוּ כׇּל הַמּוֹעֲדִים כּוּלָּם זֶה לָזֶה, שֶׁכּוּלָּן מְכַפְּרִים עַל טוּמְאַת מִקְדָּשׁ וְקָדָשָׁיו.
human_translation: And the Rabbis for Rabbi Yona, as Rabbi Yona said: All the Festivals are equated with each other, atone for the impurity of the Temple and its sacred objects,
llm_translation: The sages — that one according to Rabbi Yonah. For Rabbi Yonah said: All the festivals are interconnected, for all of them atone for the impurity of the Sanctuary and its holy items.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, מַאי טַעְמָא? דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: לֹא יֵאָמֵר ״חַג הַסּוּכּוֹת״, שֶׁבּוֹ דִּיבֵּר הַכָּתוּב, לָמָּה נֶאֱמַר — לוֹמַר שֶׁזֶּה גּוֹרֵם.
human_translation: And Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, what is the rationale as it is taught Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: It was not necessary for to mention “the festival of Sukkot ” of which the text was speaking. why is it stated? to say that this causes
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar son of Rabbi Shimon, what is the reason? As it was taught, Rabbi Elazar son of Rabbi Shimon says: One should not say "the Festival of Sukkot," in which the Scripture spoke, why is it said? To say that this causes.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב: הַאי ״בְּחַג הַמַּצּוֹת וּבְחַג הַשָּׁבוּעוֹת וּבְחַג הַסּוּכּוֹת״ מַאי דָּרְשׁוּ בֵּיהּ? מִיבְּעֵי לְהוּ לְכִדְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אָמַר רַבִּי אוֹשַׁעְיָא. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אָמַר רַבִּי אוֹשַׁעְיָא: מִנַּיִין לַעֲצֶרֶת שֶׁיֵּשׁ לָהּ תַּשְׁלוּמִין כׇּל שִׁבְעָה? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״בְּחַג הַמַּצּוֹת וּבְחַג הַשָּׁבוּעוֹת וּבְחַג הַסּוּכּוֹת״, מַקִּישׁ חַג הַשָּׁבוּעוֹת לְחַג הַמַּצּוֹת: מָה חַג הַמַּצּוֹת יֵשׁ לוֹ תַּשְׁלוּמִין כׇּל שִׁבְעָה — אַף חַג הַשָּׁבוּעוֹת יֵשׁ לוֹ תַּשְׁלוּמִין כׇּל שִׁבְעָה.
human_translation: And Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, what do they expound this “On the festival of Passover, and on the festival of Shavuot , and on the festival of Sukkot ”? They require for that Rabbi Elazar Rabbi Oshaya said, as Rabbi Elazar said Rabbi Oshaya said: From where that the Shavuot has redress all seven The verse states: “On the festival of Passover, and on the festival of Shavuot , and on the festival of Sukkot ,” equating the festival of Shavuot to the festival of Passover. Just as the festival of Passover has redress all seven so too, the festival of Shavuot has redress all seven
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov: This "on the Festival of Matzot, and on the Festival of Weeks, and on the Festival of Sukkot," what did they expound in it? They wanted to say according to Rabbi Elazar who said Rabbi Oshaya. For Rabbi Elazar said Rabbi Oshaya: From where do we derive that Shavuot, which has accompanying offerings for seven days? The verse teaches: "on the Festival of Matzot, and on the Festival of Weeks, and on the Festival of Sukkot," it compares the Festival of Weeks to the Festival of Matzot: Just as the Festival of Matzot has accompanying offerings for seven days - so too the Festival of Weeks has accompanying offerings for seven days.

hebrew_text: וְלַיקִּשׁ לְחַג הַסּוּכּוֹת: מָה לְּהַלָּן שְׁמוֹנָה — אַף כָּאן שְׁמוֹנָה! שְׁמִינִי רֶגֶל בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ הוּא.
human_translation: draw an analogy to the festival of Sukkot , Just as below, eight so too, here, eight the eighth is Festival in and of itself.
llm_translation: And he will establish for the Festival of Sukkot: Just as there, eight — so too here, eight! The eighth day is distinct by itself.

hebrew_text: אֵימוֹר דְּאָמְרִינַן שְׁמִינִי רֶגֶל בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ לְעִנְיַן פָּזֵ״ר קָשֶׁ״ב, אֲבָל לְעִנְיַין תַּשְׁלוּמִין — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל תַּשְׁלוּמִין דְּרִאשׁוֹן הוּא!
human_translation: can’t you say that we say the Eighth is a Festival in and of itself with regard to peh , zayin , reish , kuf , shin , beit , But with regard to the matter of redress everyone agrees redress for the first day
llm_translation: Statement that we say: "The eighth day is considered independently regarding the laws of scattering and regarding the laws of payments - the words of all sages are that regarding payments, the first day is considered!

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן: מִי שֶׁלֹּא חָג יוֹם טוֹב הָרִאשׁוֹן שֶׁל חַג — חוֹגֵג אֶת כָּל הָרֶגֶל וְיוֹם טוֹב הָאַחֲרוֹן שֶׁל חַג.
human_translation: As we learned If one did not bring Festival peace-offering on the first day of the festival he may bring Festival peace-offering during all of the Festival and the last day of the Festival,
llm_translation: We have learned in a Mishnah: One who did not celebrate the first day of the festival, he celebrates all the pilgrimage festival and the last day of the festival.

hebrew_text: תָּפַשְׂתָּ מְרוּבֶּה — לֹא תָּפַשְׂתָּ, תָּפַשְׂתָּ מוּעָט — תָּפַשְׂתָּ.
human_translation: If you grasped many, you did not grasp anything; if you grasped few, you grasped something.
llm_translation: You have seized the majority - you have not seized; you have seized the minority - you have seized.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא כַּתְבֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא לְחַג הַסּוּכּוֹת? לְאַקּוֹשֵׁיהּ לְחַג הַמַּצּוֹת:
human_translation: But with regard to what halakha did the Merciful One write the festival of Sukkot to draw an analogy to the festival of Passover
llm_translation: Rather, for what purpose did the Merciful One write it the Torah regarding the festival of Sukkot? To connect it to the festival of Matzot.

hebrew_text: מָה חַג הַמַּצּוֹת טָעוּן לִינָה — אַף חַג הַסּוּכּוֹת טָעוּן לִינָה.
human_translation: Just as the festival of Passover requires remaining so too, the festival of Sukkot requires remaining overnight
llm_translation: "What the festival of Matzot requires, so too the festival of Sukkot requires."

hebrew_text: וְהָתָם מְנָלַן? דִּכְתִיב: ״וּפָנִיתָ בַבֹּקֶר וְהָלַכְתָּ לְאֹהָלֶיךָ״.
human_translation: And there, from where do we As it is written and you shall turn in the morning, and go to your tents”
llm_translation: And there, how do we derive it? As it is written: "And you shall turn in the morning and go to your tents."

hebrew_text: וְתַנָּא קַמָּא וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן (בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר) — תַּשְׁלוּמִין לַעֲצֶרֶת מְנָא לְהוּ?
human_translation: And the first tanna and Rabbi Shimon, from where do they the Shavuot has redress
llm_translation: And it was taught in the first Tanna and Rabbi Shimon (ben Elazar) — are the additional offerings for Shavuot counted separately?

hebrew_text: נָפְקָא לְהוּ מִדְּתָנֵי רַבָּה בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל. דְּתָנֵי רַבָּה בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל: אָמְרָה תּוֹרָה מְנֵה יָמִים וְקַדֵּשׁ חֹדֶשׁ, מְנֵה יָמִים וְקַדֵּשׁ עֲצֶרֶת. מָה חֹדֶשׁ לִמְנוּיָו — אַף עֲצֶרֶת לִמְנוּיָו.
human_translation: They derive it from which Rabba bar Shmuel taught, as Rabba bar Shmuel taught: The Torah states to count days, and sanctify month And count days and sanctify Shavuot Just as the month is for by which it is counted, so too, Shavuot is for by which it is counted,
llm_translation: Proceeded to them from the teaching of Rabba bar Shmuel. For Rabba bar Shmuel taught: The Torah said, "Count days and sanctify the month, count days and sanctify the festival." Just as the month is for its appointment, so too the festival is for its appointment.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא עֲצֶרֶת חַד יוֹמָא? אָמַר רָבָא: אַטּוּ עֲצֶרֶת יוֹמֵי מָנִינַן, שָׁבוּעֵי לָא מָנִינַן? וְהָאָמַר מָר: מִצְוָה לְמִימְנֵי יוֹמֵי, וּמִצְוָה לְמִימְנֵי שָׁבוּעֵי. וְעוֹד: ״חַג שָׁבוּעוֹת״ כְּתִיב.
human_translation: say Shavuot one day, Rava said: Is that to say we count days until Shavuot , we do not count weeks? But didn’t the Master say: a mitzva to count days, and a mitzva to count weeks, Shavuot And further, it is written “The festival of weeks [ Shavuot ],”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Why is Shavuot one day? Rava said: If we count the days of Shavuot, do we not count the weeks? And Mar said: It is a mitzvah to count the days, and it is a mitzvah to count the weeks. Furthermore, it is written: "The Feast of Weeks."

hebrew_text: וּפֶסַח בַּר מִיקְרַב בִּרְגָלִים הוּא? פֶּסַח זִימְנָא קְבִיעָא לֵיהּ, אִי אַקְרְבֵיהּ — אַקְרְבֵיהּ, וְאִי לָא אַקְרְבֵיהּ — אִידְּחִי לֵיהּ!
human_translation: But is the Paschal lamb fit to be sacrificed on the Festivals? The Paschal lamb has a fixed time if one sacrificed it he has sacrificed it, but if he did not sacrifice it it is excluded
llm_translation: "And Pesach, is it brought near during the festivals? Pesach is a fixed time for it, if I bring it near - I bring it near, and if I do not bring it near - it is pushed away!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: פֶּסַח כְּדִי נַסְבֵהּ.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: The Paschal lamb is cited for no reason [ kedi ];
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: "Pesach as required."

hebrew_text: רַב שֵׁשֶׁת אָמַר: מַאי ״פֶּסַח״ — שַׁלְמֵי פֶסַח.
human_translation: Rav Sheshet said What is a Paschal lamb? the peace-offering in place of a Paschal lamb.
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet said: What is "Pesach" - the peace offerings of Pesach.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי — הַיְינוּ שְׁלָמִים! תְּנָא שְׁלָמִים הַבָּאִין מֵחֲמַת פֶּסַח, וּתְנָא שְׁלָמִים הַבָּאִין מֵחֲמַת עַצְמָן. סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וּמֵחֲמַת פֶּסַח קָאָתוּ,
human_translation: If so, this is peace-offerings taught peace-offerings brought in place of a Paschal lamb, and it taught peace-offerings brought independently. it might enter your mind to say: Since are brought in place of a Paschal lamb,
llm_translation: So it is — that is the same as peace offerings! A Tanna taught: Peace offerings that come because of the Passover, and a Tanna taught: Peace offerings that come because of themselves. Is it your opinion that I would say: Since they come because of the Passover,

hebrew_text: כְּפֶסַח דָּמוּ — קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: they are considered like the Paschal lamb teaches us
llm_translation: Like the Passover, his blood — is teaching us.

hebrew_text: מְנָהָנֵי מִילֵּי? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״כִּי תִדּוֹר נֶדֶר״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא נֶדֶר. נְדָבָה מִנַּיִן?
human_translation: From where are these matters derived As the Sages taught “When you shall vow a vow I have only a vow- a gift-offering, From where
llm_translation: Talmudic text: What are the sources of words? For the Rabbis taught: "When you make a vow," I have only a vow. Where is a freewill offering derived from?

hebrew_text: נֶאֱמַר כָּאן ״נֶדֶר״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״אִם נֶדֶר אוֹ נְדָבָה״. מָה לְהַלָּן — נְדָבָה עִמּוֹ, אַף כָּאן — נְדָבָה עִמּוֹ.
human_translation: It is stated here: “Vow,” and it is stated elsewhere: “But if a vow or a gift-offering” Just as there a gift-offering is with so too, here, a gift-offering is
llm_translation: It is stated here "neder," and it is stated there "if a neder or a nedavah." Just as there - a nedavah with it, so too here - a nedavah with it.

hebrew_text: ״לַה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ״ — אֵלּוּ הַדָּמִין הָעֲרָכִין וְהַחֲרָמִין וְהַהֶקְדֵּשׁוֹת. ״לֹא תְאַחֵר לְשַׁלְּמוֹ״ — הוּא וְלֹא חִילּוּפָיו. ״כִּי דָרוֹשׁ יִדְרְשֶׁנּוּ״ — אֵלּוּ חַטָּאוֹת וַאֲשָׁמוֹת עוֹלוֹת וּשְׁלָמִים.
human_translation: “To the Lord your God.” This Assessments, valuations, dedications, and consecrations. “You shall not delay paying it” it, but not its substitute, “For will surely require it these are sin-offerings, guilt-offerings, burnt-offerings, and peace-offerings.
llm_translation: "To the Lord your God" — These are the monetary valuations, consecrations, and things devoted to destruction. "Do not delay in paying it" — This refers to the principal amount and not its substitutions. "For he shall surely make restitution" — These are sin offerings, guilt offerings, burnt offerings, and peace offerings.

hebrew_text: ״ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ״ — אֵלּוּ צְדָקוֹת וּמַעַשְׂרוֹת וּבְכוֹר. ״מֵעִמָּךְ״ — זֶה לֶקֶט שִׁכְחָה וּפֵאָה. ״וְהָיָה בְךָ חֵטְא״ — וְלֹא בְּקׇרְבָּנְךָ חֵטְא.
human_translation: the Lord your God” these are charity, and tithes, and firstborn “From you”; this gleanings, forgotten sheaves, and corner “And it would be sin in you”; but there would be no sin in your offering,
llm_translation: "The Lord your God" — these are righteousness, tithes, and first fruits. "From you" — this refers to gleanings, forgotten sheaves, and corners of the field. "And there shall be sin in you" — and not sin in your offering.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: ״לֹא תְאַחֵר לְשַׁלְּמוֹ״ — הוּא וְלֹא חִילּוּפָיו. חִילּוּפֵי מַאי? אִי חִילּוּפֵי עוֹלָה וּשְׁלָמִים — מִקְרָב קָרְבִי.
human_translation: The Master said, “You shall not delay paying it” it, but not its substitute, A substitute for what If a substitute for a burnt-offering or a peace-offering, is sacrificed
llm_translation: Master said: "Do not delay to pay" — this and not its substitutions. What are its substitutions? If the substitutions are burnt offerings and peace offerings — they should be brought near my altar.

hebrew_text: אִי חִילּוּפֵי חַטָּאת, לְמִיתָה אָזְלָא. אֶלָּא מַאי חִילּוּפָיו — חִילּוּפֵי תוֹדָה.
human_translation: If a substitute for a sin-offering, is left to die, Rather, what substitute the substitute for a thanks-offering.
llm_translation: If the substitutions of the sin-offering, to death it goes. Rather, what are its substitutions? The substitutions of the thanksgiving-offering.

hebrew_text: דְּתָנֵי רַבִּי חִיָּיא: תּוֹדָה שֶׁנִּתְעָרְבָה בִּתְמוּרָתָהּ, וּמֵתָה אַחַת מֵהֶן — חֲבֶרְתָּהּ אֵין לָהּ תַּקָּנָה.
human_translation: As Rabbi Ḥiyya taught a thanks-offering that became mixed up with its substitute, and one of them died, there is no remedy for the other one,
llm_translation: It was taught by Rabbi Chiya: A thanksgiving offering that became mixed with its exchange, and one of them died - her companion does not have a remedy.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי לֶיעְבֵּיד? לַיקְרְבַהּ וְלַיקְרֵיב לֶחֶם בַּהֲדַהּ — דִּלְמָא תְּמוּרָה הִיא. לַיקְרְבַהּ בְּלָא לֶחֶם — דִּלְמָא תּוֹדָה הִיא.
human_translation: What could he have done that he may sacrifice it and sacrifice the bread with it, perhaps this is the substitute, that he should sacrifice it without bread, perhaps it is the thanks-offering,
llm_translation: How should he do it? To bring it close and to offer bread with it - perhaps it is a substitution. To bring it close without bread - perhaps it is a thanksgiving offering.

hebrew_text: וְהָא כֵּיוָן דְּלָאו בַּת הַקְרָבָה הִיא, קְרָא לְמַעוֹטֵי לְמָה לִי?
human_translation: But since is not fit to be sacrificed, why do I verse to exclude it
llm_translation: And the ah since not in daughter the close she, he called for to exclude for what to me?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: לְעוֹלָם לְמַעוֹטֵי חִילּוּפֵי עוֹלָה וּשְׁלָמִים, וְהָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן? כְּגוֹן שֶׁעָבְרוּ עָלָיו שְׁנֵי רְגָלִים וְהוּמַם, וְחִילְּלוֹ עַל אַחֵר, וְעָבַר עָלָיו רֶגֶל אֶחָד. סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וּמִכֹּחַ קַמָּא קָאָתֵי — כְּמַאן דְּעָבְרוּ עָלָיו שְׁלֹשָׁה רְגָלִים דָּמֵי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Rav Sheshet said: Actually, to exclude the substitute for a burnt-offering or a peace-offering. And here we are dealing with where two Festivals passed and it became blemished, and he redeemed it by another And another Festival passed it might enter your mind to say since comes in place of the first it considered as one for which three Festivals have passed; teaches us
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet said: Always to exclude the exchange of burnt offerings and peace offerings, and here with what are we dealing? For example, if two legs passed over it and were invalidated, and it was desecrated for another, and one leg passed over it. Is it not logical to say: Since he is weakened by the first invalidation — it is as if three legs passed over it, it is evident to us.

hebrew_text: וּלְרַבִּי מֵאִיר דְּאָמַר: כֵּיוָן שֶׁעָבַר עָלָיו רֶגֶל אֶחָד עוֹבֵר בְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״, מַאי אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר? אָמַר רָבָא: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן, כְּגוֹן שֶׁהוּמַם בְּתוֹךְ הָרֶגֶל, וְחִילְּלוֹ, וְעָבַר עָלָיו הָרֶגֶל. סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וּמִכֹּחַ קַמָּא קָאָתֵי — כְּמַאן דְּעָבַר עֲלֵיהּ כּוּלֵּיהּ רֶגֶל דָּמֵי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: but Rabbi Meir, who said: Once the first Festival has passed one transgresses You shall not delay, what is there to say Rava said: Here, we are dealing with where became blemished during the Festival, and one redeemed it and the Festival passed it might enter your mind to say since comes in place of the first it considered as one for which an entire Festival has passed, teaches us
llm_translation: And for Rabbi Meir who said: Once one foot has passed, he may not delay, what is there to say? Rava said: Here we are dealing with what he was occupied with, such as if he was distracted within the foot, and he desecrated it, and the foot passed over him. Do you think I would say: Since he is coming from the power of the previous one, whoever passes over it is considered as if he passed over the entire foot, it is evident to us.

hebrew_text: ״וְהָיָה בְּךָ חֵטְא״, וְלֹא בְּקׇרְבָּנְךָ חֵטְא. וְהָא מֵהָכָא נָפְקָא? מִדַּאֲחֵרִים נָפְקָא, דְּתַנְיָא, אֲחֵרִים אוֹמְרִים: יָכוֹל יְהֵא בְּכוֹר שֶׁעָבְרָה שְׁנָתוֹ כִּפְסוּלֵי הַמּוּקְדָּשִׁין, וְיִפָּסֵל —
human_translation: “And it would be sin in you,” but there would be no sin in your offering, Is it from here that this is learned? isn’t it derived of Aḥerim ? As it is taught Aḥerim say might that a firstborn after its year passed, should be like consecrated things that have become disqualified and it is disqualified
llm_translation: "And it shall be a sin in you," and not a sin in your offering. And from where is this derived? It is derived from elsewhere, as it is taught: Others say, "One might think that a firstborn animal that has passed its year is disqualified like the consecrated animals, and it shall be disqualified—"

hebrew_text: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְאָכַלְתָּ לִפְנֵי ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ מַעְשַׂר דְּגָנְךָ תִּירוֹשְׁךָ וְיִצְהָרֶךָ וּבְכוֹרוֹת בְּקָרְךָ וְצֹאנֶךָ״, מַקִּישׁ בְּכוֹר לְמַעֲשֵׂר: מָה מַעֲשֵׂר אֵינוֹ נִפְסָל מִשָּׁנָה לַחֲבֶרְתָּהּ, אַף בְּכוֹר אֵינוֹ נִפְסָל מִשָּׁנָה לַחֲבֶרְתָּהּ.
human_translation: the verse states: “And you shall eat before the Lord your God, the tithe of your grain, of your wine, and of your oil, and the firstborns of your herds, and of your flocks” juxtaposing a firstborn to the tithe Just as tithe is not disqualified from one year to the next, so too, a firstborn is not disqualified from one year to the next,
llm_translation: The Talmud teaches: "And you shall eat before the Lord your God, in the place which He shall choose to cause His name to dwell there, the tithe of your grain, of your wine, and of your oil, and the firstlings of your herd and of your flock." It draws an analogy between the firstborn and the tithe: Just as a tithe does not become disqualified through being exchanged for another, so too a firstborn does not become disqualified through being exchanged for another.

hebrew_text: אִיצְטְרִיךְ, סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הָנֵי מִילֵּי בְּכוֹר, דְּלָאו בַּר הַרְצָאָה הוּא, אֲבָל קׇדָשִׁים, דִּבְנֵי הַרְצָאָה נִינְהוּ — אֵימָא לָא לִירַצּוֹ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: was necessary. it might enter your mind to say this applies a firstborn, which is not for appeasement, But consecrated which appease, say they do not appease teaches us
llm_translation: It is necessary, as your mind has concluded: these matters of firstborn, which are not of the offspring of a non-priest, but consecrated items, which are considered offspring of a non-priest — say it is not for his benefit, this is what we understand.

hebrew_text: וְאַכַּתִּי,
human_translation: But still,
llm_translation: And once.

hebrew_text: מִדְּבֶן עַזַּאי נָפְקָא, דְּתַנְיָא: בֶּן עַזַּאי אוֹמֵר: ״אוֹתוֹ״
human_translation: is derived from which ben Azzai as it is taught ben Azzai says: it,
llm_translation: From the school of Azai came out, as it was taught: Ben Azai says: "That same one."

hebrew_text: מַה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר? לְפִי שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא תְאַחֵר לְשַׁלְּמוֹ״, שׁוֹמֵעַ אֲנִי אַף מְאַחֵר נִדְרוֹ בְּ״בַל יֵרָצֶה״, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אוֹתוֹ״ — אוֹתוֹ בְּ״לֹא יֵרָצֶה״, וְאֵין מְאַחֵר נִדְרוֹ בְּ״לֹא יֵרָצֶה״,
human_translation: what the verse state Since it states: you shall not delay paying it; I might have interpreted even one who is late his vow It shall not be accepted. the verse states “it.” It, is “It shall not be accepted,” but one who is late his vow is not in “It shall not be accepted.”
llm_translation: What does the Talmud say? Because it is stated: "Do not delay to pay it," I might think that one may also delay his vow in "without delay." The Talmud teaches us to say: "that" - that in "without delay," but one may not delay his vow in "without delay."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: ״בְּךָ חֵטְא״ — וְלֹא בְּאִשְׁתְּךָ חֵטְא.
human_translation: rather, sin in you” but not a sin in your wife.
llm_translation: Rather: "In you is the sin" — and not "In your wife is the sin."

hebrew_text: סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וְאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, וְאִי תֵּימָא רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: אֵין אִשְׁתּוֹ שֶׁל אָדָם מֵתָה אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן מְבַקְּשִׁין מִמֶּנּוּ מָמוֹן וְאֵין לוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אִם אֵין לְךָ לְשַׁלֵּם לָמָּה יִקַּח מִשְׁכָּבְךָ מִתַּחְתֶּיךָ״, אֵימָא בְּהַאי עָוֹן דְּ״בַל תְּאַחֵר״ נָמֵי אִשְׁתּוֹ מֵתָה, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: It might enter your mind to say: Since Rabbi Yoḥanan said, and some say Rabbi Elazar A person’s wife dies only because demand of him money and he does not have as it is stated “If you have nothing with which to pay, why should he take away your bed from under you?” say that wife also dies for this transgression You shall not delay, the verse teaches us
llm_translation: I ascend of your opinion: Since Rabbi Yochanan said, and if you will say Rabbi Elazar: A man's wife only dies if they demand money from him and he does not have it, as it is said: "If you have nothing to pay, why should he take your bed from under you." Say also in this sin of "do not delay," his wife also dies, it is heard for us.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״מוֹצָא שְׂפָתֶיךָ״ — זוֹ מִצְוַת עֲשֵׂה, ״תִּשְׁמוֹר״ — זוֹ מִצְוַת לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה, ״וְעָשִׂיתָ״ — אַזְהָרָה לְבֵית דִּין שֶׁיְּעַשּׂוּךְ, ״כַּאֲשֶׁר נָדַרְתָּ״ — זֶה נֶדֶר, ״לַה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ״ — אֵלּוּ חַטָּאוֹת וַאֲשָׁמוֹת עוֹלוֹת וּשְׁלָמִים, ״נְדָבָה״ — כְּמַשְׁמָעוֹ, ״אֲשֶׁר דִּבַּרְתָּ״ — אֵלּוּ קׇדְשֵׁי בֶּדֶק הַבַּיִת, ״בְּפִיךְ״ — זוֹ צְדָקָה.
human_translation: The Sages taught “That which is gone out of your lips”; this is a positive mitzva. “You shall keep”; this is a prohibition, “And do”; an admonition to the court to make you “As you have vowed”; this a vow-offering. “To the Lord your God”; this sin-offerings, guilt-offerings, burnt-offerings, and peace-offerings, gift”; in its literal sense “Which you have promised”; this objects consecrated for Temple maintenance. “With your mouth”; this charity,
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "From your lips" - this is a positive commandment, "you shall observe" - this is a negative commandment, "and you shall perform" - a warning to the court that they should make you do it, "as you have vowed" - this is a vow, "to the Lord your God" - these are sin offerings, guilt offerings, burnt offerings, and peace offerings, "a freewill offering" - as it sounds, "that you have spoken" - these are the funds for the Temple treasury, "from your mouth" - this is charity.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: ״מוֹצָא שְׂפָתֶיךָ״ — זוֹ מִצְוַת עֲשֵׂה. לְמָה לִי? מִ״וּבָאתָ שָּׁמָּה ... וַהֲבֵאתֶם שָׁמָּה״ נָפְקָא! ״תִּשְׁמוֹר״ — זוֹ מִצְוַת לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה. לְמָה לִי? מִ״לֹּא תְאַחֵר לְשַׁלְּמוֹ״ נָפְקָא!
human_translation: The Master said: “That which is gone out of your lips”; this is a positive mitzva. Why do I Isn’t derived “And there you shall come; and there you shall bring “You shall keep”; this is a prohibition. Why do I this is derived “You shall not delay paying it”
llm_translation: The Master said: "From the utterance of your lips" — this is a positive commandment. Why do I need it? From "and you shall bring there" it is derived! "You shall observe" — this is a negative commandment. Why do I need it? From "do not delay to pay it" it is derived!

hebrew_text: ״וְעָשִׂיתָ״ — אַזְהָרָה לְבֵית דִּין שֶׁיְּעַשּׂוּךְ. לְמָה לִי? מִ״יַּקְרִיב אוֹתוֹ״ נָפְקָא, דְּתַנְיָא: ״יַקְרִיב אוֹתוֹ״ — מְלַמֵּד שֶׁכּוֹפִין אוֹתוֹ. יָכוֹל בְּעַל כׇּרְחוֹ — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לִרְצוֹנוֹ״, הָא כֵּיצַד? כּוֹפִין אוֹתוֹ עַד שֶׁיֹּאמַר ״רוֹצֶה אֲנִי״.
human_translation: “And do”; a warning to the court to make you Why do I is derived “He shall offer it” as it is taught “He shall offer it,” teaches that he must be forced might against his will. the verse states: “In accordance with his will” How so? The coerces him until he says: I want to
llm_translation: "And you shall make" — a warning to the court that they should compel you. Why do I need it? From "he shall offer it" it is derived, as it was taught: "He shall offer it" — teaches that they force him. Could it be against his will? The verse teaches: "voluntarily," how so? They force him until he says, "I am willing."

hebrew_text: חַד, דַּאֲמַר וְלָא אַפְרֵישׁ, וְחַד, אַפְרֵישׁ וְלָא אַקְרֵיב.
human_translation: One where one said but did not set aside one where he set aside but did not sacrifice
llm_translation: One, who said and did not separate, and one, separated and did not offer.

hebrew_text: וּצְרִיכָא, דְּאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן אֲמַר וְלָא אַפְרֵישׁ, מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא קַיְּימֵיהּ לְדִיבּוּרֵיהּ, אֲבָל אַפְרֵישׁ וְלָא אַקְרֵיב, אֵימָא: כֹּל הֵיכָא דְּאִיתֵיהּ — בֵּי גַזָּא דְּרַחֲמָנָא אִיתֵיהּ. צְרִיכָא.
human_translation: And it is necessary as had taught us one said but did not set aside because he did not keep his word; however, if he set aside but did not sacrifice say anywhere that it is, it is in the treasure house of the Merciful One, it is necessary
llm_translation: The matter requires, for if we were to hear someone say "and not separate," because he does not establish it for his words, but if he were to separate and not offer, say: wherever he is present - the treasury of the Merciful One is present. It is necessary.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן אַפְרֵישׁ וְלָא אַקְרֵיב, דְּקָא מַשְׁהֵי לֵיהּ גַּבֵּיהּ, אֲבָל אָמַר וְלָא אַפְרֵישׁ, אֵימָא דִּיבּוּרָא לֹא כְּלוּם הוּא. צְרִיכָא.
human_translation: And had taught us one set aside but did not sacrifice because he is keeping for himself. But if he said but did not set aside say speech is nothing, it necessary
llm_translation: And if we were to say "separate" but not "offer," for he is delaying it, but if he were to say "and not separate," we might say that speech is nothing. This is necessary.
