hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מוֹדִים חֲכָמִים לְרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל. וְרַב אֲמַר: עֲדַיִין הִיא מַחְלוֹקֶת. שַׁמְעַהּ רַבִּי חִיָּיא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבָּה בַּר נַחְמָנִי, אֲזַל, אַמְרַהּ לִשְׁמַעְתָּא קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב דִּימִי בַּר חִינָּנָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ, הָכִי אָמַר רַב: עֲדַיִין הִיא מַחְלוֹקֶת. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה נָמֵי הָכִי קָאָמַר. כִּי אֲמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן לְהָא שְׁמַעְתָּא, אִפְּלִיג עֲלֵיהּ רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ וַאֲמַר: עֲדַיִין הִיא מַחְלוֹקֶת.
human_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: the Rabbis concede to Rabban Gamliel. But Rav said: It is still a dispute Rabbi Ḥiyya, son of Rabba bar Naḥmani, heard this and went and stated halakha before Rav Dimi bar Ḥinnana. He said to him this is what Rav said: It is still a dispute. said to him: This is what Rabba bar bar Ḥana also said: When Rabbi Yoḥanan said this halakha , Reish Lakish disagreed with him and said: It is still a dispute.
llm_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: The Sages concede to Rabban Gamliel. And Rav said: It is still a dispute. Rabbi Ḥiyya, son of Rabba bar Naḥmani, heard this, went, and said it before Rav Dimi bar Ḥinnana. He said to him, thus said Rav: It is still a dispute. He said to him: Rabba bar bar Ḥana also said the same. For when Rabbi Yoḥanan said this teaching, Reish Lakish disagreed with him and said: It is still a dispute.

hebrew_text: וּמִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן הָכִי? וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי חָנָה צִיפּוֹרָאָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הִלְכְתָא כְּרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל, הִלְכְתָא מִכְּלָל דִּפְלִיגִי!
human_translation: And did Rabbi Yoḥanan say this? Didn’t Rabbi Ḥana from Tzippori say Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabban Gamliel? The halakha , by inference disagree.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And who said it, Rabbi Yochanan like this? And Rabbi Chanah the birdwatcher said, Rabbi Yochanan said: The halakha is like Rabban Gamliel, the halakha is from the general principle that they disputed!" English translation:

hebrew_text: כִּי סְלֵיק רַבִּי אַבָּא מִיַּמֵּי, פֵּירְשַׁהּ: מוֹדִים חֲכָמִים לְרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל בִּבְרָכוֹת שֶׁל רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה וְשֶׁל יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים, וַהֲלָכָה מִכְּלָל דִּפְלִיגִי בִּבְרָכוֹת דְּכׇל הַשָּׁנָה.
human_translation: When Rabbi Abba returned from at sea, he explained The Sages concede to Rabban Gamliel to the blessings of Rosh HaShana and of Yom Kippur, And the halakha by inference, that disagree, to the blessings of the entire year.
llm_translation: When Rabbi Abba ascended from his days, he explained: The sages concede to Rabban Gamliel regarding the blessings of Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, and the halacha is derived from the general principle that they disputed in blessings throughout the year.

hebrew_text: אִינִי?! וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי חָנָה צִיפּוֹרָאָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל בִּבְרָכוֹת שֶׁל רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה וְשֶׁל יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים!
human_translation: Is that so? Didn’t Rabbi Ḥana from Tzippori say Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabban Gamliel with the blessings of Rosh HaShana and of Yom Kippur?
llm_translation: I?! But didn't Rabbi Ḥanina the bird-seller say in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: The halakha is in accordance with Rabban Gamliel in the blessings of Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: מַאן מוֹדִים — רַבִּי מֵאִיר, וַהֲלָכָה מִכְּלָל דִּפְלִיגִי — רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Who concedes Rabbi Meir. And the halakha by inference, that disagree, the Rabbis,
llm_translation: Rather, said Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak: Who concedes? — Rabbi Meir, and the halacha is in accordance with the general principle of the Sages.

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: בְּרָכוֹת שֶׁל רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה וְשֶׁל יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים — שְׁלִיחַ צִבּוּר מוֹצִיא הָרַבִּים יְדֵי חוֹבָתָן, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁשְּׁלִיחַ צִבּוּר חַיָּיב — כָּךְ כָּל יָחִיד וְיָחִיד חַיָּיב.
human_translation: As it is taught the blessings of Rosh HaShana and of Yom Kippur, the prayer leader fulfills the obligation on behalf of the many. statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: Just as the prayer leader is obligated so too, every individual is obligated
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: Regarding the blessings of Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur - the emissary of the congregation fulfills the obligation on behalf of the public, according to the words of Rabbi Meir. And the Sages say: Just as the emissary of the congregation is obligated, so too, every individual is obligated.

hebrew_text: מַאי שְׁנָא הָנֵי? אִילֵּימָא מִשּׁוּם דִּנְפִישִׁי קְרָאֵי — וְהָאָמַר רַב חֲנַנְאֵל אָמַר רַב: כֵּיוָן שֶׁאָמַר ״וּבְתוֹרָתְךָ כָּתוּב לֵאמֹר״ שׁוּב אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ! אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דְּאָוְושִׁי בְּרָכוֹת.
human_translation: What is different these If we say due to the many verses Didn’t Rav Ḥananel say Rav said: Once one has recited And in Your Torah it is written, saying, it is no longer necessary Rather, because there are many blessings,
llm_translation: What is the difference between these? If you say it is because the verses are repeated - but Rav Hananel said in the name of Rav: Once it says, "And it is written in Your Torah, saying," a repetition is not necessary! Rather, it is because he was meticulous in blessings.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא, אָמַר רַב חֲנַנְאֵל אָמַר רַב: כֵּיוָן שֶׁאָמַר ״וּבְתוֹרָתְךָ כָּתוּב לֵאמֹר״ — שׁוּב אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ. סְבוּר מִינַּהּ: הָנֵי מִילֵּי בְּיָחִיד, אֲבָל בְּצִבּוּר לָא. אִתְּמַר, אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: אֶחָד יָחִיד אֶחָד צִבּוּר, כֵּיוָן שֶׁאָמַר ״וּבְתוֹרָתְךָ כָּתוּב לֵאמֹר״ — שׁוּב אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ.
human_translation: the itself. Rav Ḥananel said Rav said: Once one has recited And in Your Torah it is written, saying, it is no longer necessary understood from this it applies only to an individual; however, to a congregation, no, it is stated Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Both an individual and a congregation, once one has recited: And in Your Torah it is written, saying, it is no longer necessary
llm_translation: The body, said Rav Hananel said Rav: Once it said "and in Your Torah it is written to say" - return, it is not necessary. He thought from it: those matters in private, but in public not. It was stated, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: one individual, one public, once it said "and in Your Torah it is written to say" - return, it is not necessary.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: לְעוֹלָם יַסְדִּיר אָדָם תְּפִלָּתוֹ, וְאַחַר כָּךְ יִתְפַּלֵּל. אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא: מִסְתַּבְּרָא מִילְּתֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בִּבְרָכוֹת שֶׁל רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה וְשֶׁל יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים וְשֶׁל פְּרָקִים, אֲבָל דְּכׇל הַשָּׁנָה — לָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: A person should always arrange his prayer and then pray. Rabbi Abba said: Rabbi Elazar’s statement is reasonable to the blessings of Rosh HaShana and Yom Kippur and of intermittently. However, to all year, no,
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: A person should always arrange his prayer, and afterwards pray. Rabbi Abba said: The words of Rabbi Elazar are logical in the blessings of Rosh Hashanah, Yom Kippur, and chapters, but throughout the rest of the year - no.

hebrew_text: אִינִי?! וְהָא רַב יְהוּדָה מְסַדַּר צְלוֹתֵיהּ וּמְצַלֵּי! שָׁאנֵי רַב יְהוּדָה, כֵּיוָן דְּמִתְּלָתִין יוֹמִין לִתְלָתִין יוֹמִין הֲוָה מְצַלֵּי, כִּפְרָקִים דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Is that so? Didn’t Rav Yehuda arrange his prayer and pray, Rav Yehuda was different, since he would pray every thirty days. like intermittently.
llm_translation: I?! And isn't it so that Rav Yehudah arranges his rows and roasts them! Rav Yehudah is different, since when he would roast for three days, it would be well-roasted, like the chapters of blood.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַחָא בַּר עַוִּירָא אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן חֲסִידָא: פּוֹטֵר הָיָה רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אֲפִילּוּ עַם שֶׁבַּשָּׂדוֹת. וְלָא מִיבַּעְיָא הָנֵי דְּקָיְימִי הָכָא?!
human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Avira said Rabbi Shimon Ḥasida said: Rabban Gamliel would exempt even the people who were in the fields and needless to say, those who are here
llm_translation: Rav Acha bar Avira said, Rabbi Shimon Chasida said: Rabban Gamliel used to exempt even the people in the fields. And do these not require the fulfillment here?!

hebrew_text: אַדְּרַבָּה: הָנֵי אֲנִיסִי, הָנֵי לָא אֲנִיסִי,
human_translation: On the contrary, Those due to circumstances beyond their control, those not due to circumstances beyond their control.
llm_translation: Ad'Rabba: hanei anisi, hanei lo anisi.

hebrew_text: דְּתָנֵי אַבָּא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב בִּנְיָמִין בַּר חִיָּיא: עַם שֶׁאֲחוֹרֵי כֹּהֲנִים — אֵינָן בִּכְלַל בְּרָכָה.
human_translation: As Abba, son of Rav Binyamin bar Ḥiyya, taught people behind the priests are not included in the blessing.
llm_translation: It was taught in a baraita by Abba, son of Rav Benyamin bar Hiyya: "People who follow behind the priests - they are not included in the blessing."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא, כִּי אֲתָא רָבִין: אָמַר רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב בַּר אִידֵּי אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן חֲסִידָא: לֹא פָּטַר רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אֶלָּא עַם שֶׁבַּשָּׂדוֹת, מַאי טַעְמָא — מִשּׁוּם דַּאֲנִיסִי בִּמְלָאכָה, אֲבָל בָּעִיר — לֹא.
human_translation: Rather, When Ravin came Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi said Rabbi Shimon bar Ḥasida said: Rabban Gamliel exempt only the people in the fields. What is the reason Because due to work circumstances beyond their control, However, in the city
llm_translation: Rather, when Ravin came, Rabbi Yaakov bar Idi said in the name of Rabbi Shimon Chasida: Rabban Gamliel only exempted the people in the fields. What is the reason? Because he was lenient with work, but not in the city - no.

hebrew_text: הַדְרָן עֲלָךְ יוֹם טוֹב וּסְלִיקָא לַהּ מַסֶּכֶת רֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה
llm_translation: We will return to you, have a good day, and we will conclude with her the tractate Rosh Hashanah.
